  2. 2 A stochastic approach in projectile motion
  3. 3 A stochastic approach in statics
  4. 4 Concluding remarks
  5. A Basic knowledge of probability
  6. B Basic knowledge of mechanics

A stochastic approach in physics exercises of
mathematics education

M√°ty√°s Barczy‚àó,‚ãÑsuperscriptBarczy‚ãÑ\text{Barczy}^{*,\diamond}Barczy start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó , ‚ãÑ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ¬†Imre Kocsis‚àó‚àósuperscriptKocsisabsent\text{Kocsis}^{**}Kocsis start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ¬†Csaba G√°bor K√©zi‚àó‚àósuperscriptK√©ziabsent\text{K\'{e}zi}^{**}K√©zi start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àó ‚àó end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

* HUN-REN‚ÄìSZTE Analysis and Applications Research Group, Bolyai Institute, University of Szeged, Aradi v√©rtan√∫k tere 1, H‚Äì6720 Szeged, Hungary.

** Department of Basic Technical Studies, Faculty of Engineering, University of Debrecen, √ìtemet≈ë utca 2-4, H‚Äì4028 Debrecen, Hungary.

E-mails: barczy@math.u-szeged.hu (M. Barczy), kezicsaba@eng.unideb.hu (Cs. G. K√©zi),
kocsisi@eng.unideb.hu (I. Kocsis).

‚ãÑ‚ãÑ\diamond‚ãÑ Corresponding author.

‚Ä†‚Ä†2020 Mathematics Subject Classifications: 97K50, 97M50. ‚Ä†‚Ä†Key words and phrases: projectile motion, statics, probability theory.
Abstract

We present a method for incorporating a stochastic point of view into physics exercises of mathematics education. The core of our method is the randomization of some inputs, the system model used does not differ from what we would use in the deterministic approach. We consider exercises from the theory of projectile motion and statics. The outputs of stochastic models are random variables, and we usually determine their probability distributions, expected values, variances, and relative standard deviations, and the probabilities of some events related to them are also calculated. We primarily recommend our exercises to motivated high school students but first-year university students can also benefit from them.

1 Introduction

Deterministic and stochastic models play equally significant roles in engineering sciences and economy. However, in many countries (for example, in Hungary) a deterministic approach is at the heart of education and thus of student thinking (in particular, at high schools).

The effect of uncontrolled input (noise) on the output of a system can be negligible, but it can also be very important and lead to false conclusions. In deterministic models, we make the simplifying assumption that there is no noise. Whether this simplification causes problems in solving a real-world problem depends on how much uncertainty there is in the system‚Äôs inputs and parameters, and how sensitive the output is to this uncertainty. If we do not examine this, then we cannot judge the adequacy of the solution resulting from the deterministic model. When solving a problem, a conscious choice must be made between deterministic and stochastic models. Didactically, the applicability of the two approaches is very different. A stochastic approach is usually unavoidable when analyzing problems in engineering sciences, economy and financial mathematics. The emphasis is on seeing the difference in the output (solution of the problem under study) for deterministic and random inputs. Studying the stochastic approach is important for understanding the phenomena and processes of everyday life. For example, we constantly evaluate risks and act according to our individual risk tolerance. A person who is not familiar with the concept of risk does not understand what to expect from an investment and is unable to deal with situations that do not correspond to his or her preconcept.

There is a long tradition of the illustration of the basic ideas and calculations of probability theory in teaching using gambling games. For example, we can mention the book of Schoenberg [7] in which both standard and advanced probability topics are illustrated using the popular poker game of Texas Hold‚Äôem, rather than the typical balls in urns. Johnson [3] has chosen the gambling game of Craps for such purposes.

In this article, we present a method for incorporating a stochastic point of view into physics exercises of mathematics education. The core of the method is the randomization of some inputs, the system model used does not differ from what we would use in the deterministic approach. In our exercises, the distribution of random inputs, in most of the cases, is a uniform distribution. This does not weaken the pedagogical goal, since using inputs with more complicated distributions would not make a difference in principle, it would only make the calculations more difficult. Of course, in real life problems, more general distributions such as exponential, normal or Pareto distributions could come into play. The outputs of stochastic models are random variables, and even if the inputs are uniformly distributed, the outputs are usually not uniformly distributed. We note that in Exercise 2.4 an absolutely continuous random variable with a given density function also appears for the ratio of the rebound and landing speeds when a tennis ball is dropped on concrete from a given distance. In the exercises, we usually determine the probability distributions, expected values, variances, and relative standard deviations of the outputs, and the probabilities of some events related to them are also calculated using the basic tools of probability theory.

We demonstrate our method of randomization of some inputs by considering exercises from the theory of projectile motion and statics. According to our knowledge, this stochastic viewpoint is not widespread for problems in projectile motion, and basically is not present at high schools and at physics competitions. Nonetheless, we can mention the research paper of Montecinos et al.¬†[5] where an application of the maximum entropy inference to the problem of a two-dimensional projectile motion was investigated. Namely, given information about the average horizontal range over many realizations, they studied the problem of inferring the initial conditions, i.e., the initial angle and speed. In statics one can find several stochastic models. Here we only mention a recent paper of Cort√©s et al.¬†[1] who carried out a probabilistic analysis of the deflection of a cantilever beam subjected to random loads via density functions.

Our reason for choosing the topics of projectile motion and statics for demonstrating our method is the fact that the physics behind these two topics is relatively easy to understand, and we would like to recommend our exercises to motivated high school students. Students learn the physics of projectile motion as early as the first years of high school. However, first-year university students can also benefit from getting acquainted with these exercises. Students may be asked to create similar exercises, for other fields of physics as well.

In Appendices A and B, we collected some of the basics of probability theory and mechanics that are needed to solve the problems, respectively. Most of the content of Appendix A on the required knowledge of probability theory is covered by the syllabus of high school students specialized in mathematics, except maybe the law of total expectation. Nonetheless, we remark that the law of total expectation is used only in the solution of part (ii) of Exercise 2.1 where an alternative solution using the method of geometric probability is also presented. The content of Appendix B on some knowledge of mechanics is essentially contained in the syllabus of high school students, and hence this appendix is not so detailed.

We take great care to demonstrate the use of the tools from probability theory, and hence we provide detailed solutions to the exercises. Our stochastic perspective can help the students recognize the fact that many phenomena in our daily lives have a random nature, and therefore it can be useful to get in touch with stochastic thinking and tools in order to be able to understand these phenomena much better.

The paper is structured as follows. Sections 2 and 3 are devoted to exercises for projectile motion and statics, respectively. In Sections 2 and 3, we present five and three exercises, respectively. We close the paper with Appendices A and B, where, without being exhaustive, we recall some of the notations, conventions, concepts and results of probability theory and mechanics that are used in solving the exercises.

Next, we briefly summarize what kind of tools in probability theory we use in the exercises of Sections 2 and 3. In Exercise 2.1, among others, we use the notions of expectation, variance and relative standard deviation of an absolutely continuous random variable, and we calculate the probability of an event by two methods, namely, by the method of geometric probability and by the law of total expectation, respectively. In part (iii) of Exercise 2.1, we calculate a conditional probability as well. In Exercise 2.2, we use the notions of expectation, variance and relative standard deviation of a discrete random variable, and the additivity property of probability. In Exercise 2.3, among others, the notion of the distribution of discrete and absolute continuous random variables and the notions of expectations, variances and relative standard deviations of such random variables come into play. In Exercise 2.4, we use the fact that a probability that an absolutely continuous random variable falls in a given interval can be calculated using the density function of the random variable in question, and we provide an application of Bayes‚Äô theorem as well. In Exercise 2.5, we calculate the expected value of the relative error in some problems for free fall (i.e., for a motion of a body, where the gravity of Earth is the only force acting upon it) if instead of the precise value of the gravity of Earth we use an approximating random value for it. In this exercise, the notion of the expected value of an absolutely continuous random variable is used. In Exercises 3.2 and 3.3, 2-dimensional random variables and their expectation vectors play important roles.

The set of positive integers and real numbers is denoted by ‚Ñï‚Ñï\mathbb{N}blackboard_N and ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}blackboard_R, respectively. For a 2222-dimensional vector (x,y)‚àà‚Ñù2ùë•ùë¶superscript‚Ñù2(x,y)\in\mathbb{R}^{2}( italic_x , italic_y ) ‚àà blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, its Euclidean length is defined by ‚Äñ(x,y)‚Äñ:=x2+y2assignnormùë•ùë¶superscriptùë•2superscriptùë¶2\|(x,y)\|:=\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}‚à• ( italic_x , italic_y ) ‚à• := square-root start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. The coordinates of a vector ùíóùíó{\boldsymbol{v}}bold_italic_v in the (x,y)ùë•ùë¶(x,y)( italic_x , italic_y )-plane are denoted by vxsubscriptùë£ùë•v_{x}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vysubscriptùë£ùë¶v_{y}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively, i.e., ùíó=(vx,vy)ùíósubscriptùë£ùë•subscriptùë£ùë¶{\boldsymbol{v}}=(v_{x},v_{y})bold_italic_v = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). In the solutions, the number of significant digits is chosen to be 4 (for example, instead of 21.28521.28521.28521.285, we write 21.2921.2921.2921.29, or instead of 0.0234560.0234560.0234560.023456, we write 0.023460.023460.023460.02346). All of the physical quantities are expressed in SI units, so we do not display the units in calculations. In the calculations, the magnitude of the gravitational acceleration near the Earth‚Äôs surface is assumed to be g=9.81ùëî9.81g=9.81\,italic_g = 9.81ms2msuperscripts2\mathrm{\frac{m}{s^{2}}}divide start_ARG roman_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG.

2 A stochastic approach in projectile motion

In this section, we demonstrate our method for incorporating a stochastic point of view into physics exercises of mathematics education by presenting exercises for projectile motion. In these ones, some of the initial values, namely, the initial height and/or velocity of a launched ball, are chosen randomly to make the problems more realistic. We usually choose a uniform distribution, but in Exercise 2.4 an absolutely continuous random variable with a given density function also comes into play for the ratio of the rebound and landing speeds when a tennis ball is dropped on concrete from a given distance. In all of the exercises, we suppose that the air resistance is negligible. Altogether, we present five problems in this section.

2.1 Exercise.

Let us consider a cylindrical-shape forest lookout with a radius of 10 meters and a height of 50 meters, which stands on horizontal ground. From the bottom of the forest lookout, Thomas goes up the spiral staircase. Thomas stops at a height h‚Ñéhitalic_h chosen according to a uniform distribution on the interval [0‚Å¢m,50‚Å¢m]0m50m[0\,\mathrm{m},50\,\mathrm{m}][ 0 roman_m , 50 roman_m ], and from the edge of the forest lookout he launches a ball with velocity vùë£vitalic_v of which the magnitude is uniformly distributed on the interval [5‚Å¢ms,15‚Å¢ms]5ms15ms[5\,\mathrm{\frac{m}{s}},15\,\mathrm{\frac{m}{s}}][ 5 divide start_ARG roman_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_s end_ARG , 15 divide start_ARG roman_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_s end_ARG ], and its direction is perpendicular to the wall of the forest lookout. We suppose that h‚Ñéhitalic_h and vùë£vitalic_v are independent.

  • (i)

    What is the expected value, variance and relative standard deviation of the distance of which the ball hits the ground from the wall of the forest lookout?

  • (ii)

    Suppose that the forest lookout is surrounded by an annulus-shape fence to which the top is horizontal. The two walls of the fence (inner and outer circles) are 10101010 meters and 10.510.510.510.5 meters from the wall of the forest lookout, respectively. The height of the fence is 2222 meters. On Figure 1, the plane section determined by the direction of the shot is shown, and only the part of the fence in the direction of the shot is plotted. What is the probability that the ball first hits one of the line segments B‚Å¢Cùêµùê∂BCitalic_B italic_C and C‚Å¢Dùê∂ùê∑CDitalic_C italic_D (see Figure 1), that is, the ball first hits the fence?

  • (iii)

    Suppose that the forest lookout is surrounded by the same annulus-shape fence described in part (ii). Further, suppose that the ball first hits the line segment A‚Å¢Bùê¥ùêµABitalic_A italic_B (that is, the ball first hits the ground in front of the fence but misses it). What is the probability that Thomas launched the ball from lower than 10 meters?

Solution. It is known that if we launch a ball horizontally at height h‚Ñéhitalic_h with velocity vùë£vitalic_v, then the total (horizontal) distance of the whole journey before the ball hits the ground is d:=2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖvassignùëë‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëîùë£d:=\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot vitalic_d := square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ italic_v. Further, if the ball takes a distance xùë•xitalic_x horizontally, then it takes a vertical distance g2‚Å¢v2‚ãÖx2‚ãÖùëî2superscriptùë£2superscriptùë•2\frac{g}{2v^{2}}\cdot x^{2}divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚ãÖ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, see Figure 2 as well:

By our assumptions, h‚Ñéhitalic_h is a uniformly distributed random variable on the interval [0,50]050[0,50][ 0 , 50 ], vùë£vitalic_v is a uniformly distributed random variable on the interval [5,15]515[5,15][ 5 , 15 ], and furthermore, h‚Ñéhitalic_h and vùë£vitalic_v are independent.

(i). Then h‚Ñé\sqrt{h}square-root start_ARG italic_h end_ARG and vùë£vitalic_v are also independent, hence, using the homogeneity of expectation (see (A.2)), we get that

Now, we turn to calculate the variance and standard deviation of dùëëditalic_d. Using that h‚Ñéhitalic_h and v2superscriptùë£2v^{2}italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are independent, we obtain that

ùîº‚Å°(d2)ùîºsuperscriptùëë2\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(d^{2})blackboard_E ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =ùîº‚Å°((2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖv)2)=ùîº‚Å°(2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖv2)=2g‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(h)‚ãÖùîº‚Å°(v2)=2g‚Å¢‚à´050p‚ãÖ150‚Å¢dp‚ãÖ‚à´515r2‚ãÖ110‚Å¢drabsentùîºsuperscript‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëîùë£2ùîº‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëîsuperscriptùë£2‚ãÖ2ùëîùîº‚Ñéùîºsuperscriptùë£22ùëîsuperscriptsubscript050‚ãÖ‚ãÖùëù150differential-dùëùsuperscriptsubscript515‚ãÖsuperscriptùëü2110differential-dùëü\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot v% \right)^{2}\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{2h}{g}\cdot v^{2}% \right)=\frac{2}{g}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(h)\cdot\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(% v^{2})=\frac{2}{g}\int_{0}^{50}p\cdot\frac{1}{50}\,\mathrm{d}p\cdot\int_{5}^{1% 5}r^{2}\cdot\frac{1}{10}\,\mathrm{d}r= blackboard_E ( ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ italic_v ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ‚ãÖ italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG blackboard_E ( italic_h ) ‚ãÖ blackboard_E ( italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG roman_d italic_p ‚ãÖ ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG roman_d italic_r

Consequently, the variance of dùëëditalic_d takes the form

ùîª2‚Å°(d)=ùîº‚Å°(d2)‚àí(ùîº‚Å°(d))2=162503‚Å¢g‚àí400009‚Å¢g=87509‚Å¢g‚âà99.11,superscriptùîª2ùëëùîºsuperscriptùëë2superscriptùîºùëë2162503ùëî400009ùëî87509ùëî99.11\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}^{2}(d)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(d^{2})-(% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(d))^{2}=\frac{16250}{3g}-\frac{40000}{9g}=\frac{8750% }{9g}\approx 99.11,blackboard_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) = blackboard_E ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - ( blackboard_E ( italic_d ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 16250 end_ARG start_ARG 3 italic_g end_ARG - divide start_ARG 40000 end_ARG start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG = divide start_ARG 8750 end_ARG start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG ‚âà 99.11 ,

and hence the standard deviation of dùëëditalic_d is

ùîª‚Å°(d)=25‚Å¢143‚Å¢g‚âà9.955.ùîªùëë25143ùëî9.955\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}(d)=\frac{25\sqrt{14}}{3\sqrt{g}}\approx 9.955.blackboard_D ( italic_d ) = divide start_ARG 25 square-root start_ARG 14 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚âà 9.955 .

This implies that the relative standard deviation of dùëëditalic_d is

RSD‚Å°(d)=25‚Å¢143‚Å¢g2003‚Å¢g=148‚âà0.4677.RSDùëë25143ùëî2003ùëî1480.4677\operatorname{RSD}(d)=\frac{\frac{25\sqrt{14}}{3\sqrt{g}}}{\frac{200}{3\sqrt{g% }}}=\frac{\sqrt{14}}{8}\approx 0.4677.roman_RSD ( italic_d ) = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG 25 square-root start_ARG 14 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG 200 end_ARG start_ARG 3 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG = divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 14 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ‚âà 0.4677 .

(ii). Let us introduce the events RùëÖRitalic_R and SùëÜSitalic_S:

R:={the ball‚Äôs (first) point of impact is in the line segment¬†A‚Å¢B}={d<10},assignùëÖthe ball‚Äôs (first) point of impact is in the line segment¬†A‚Å¢Bùëë10\displaystyle R:=\Big{\{}\text{the ball's (first) point of impact is in the % line segment $AB$}\Big{\}}=\Big{\{}d<10\Big{\}},italic_R := { the ball‚Äôs (first) point of impact is in the line segment italic_A italic_B } = { italic_d < 10 } ,

={g2‚Å¢v2‚ãÖ10.52<h‚àí2}.absent‚ãÖùëî2superscriptùë£2superscript10.52‚Ñé2\displaystyle\phantom{:=\,}=\Big{\{}\frac{g}{2v^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{2}<h-2\Big{\}}.= { divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚ãÖ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_h - 2 } .

Then we get that

(2.1) ‚Ñô‚Å°({the ball hits the fence before it hits the ground})=1‚àí‚Ñô‚Å°(R)‚àí‚Ñô‚Å°(S).‚Ñô{the ball hits the fence before it hits the ground}1‚ÑôùëÖ‚ÑôùëÜ\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\big{(}\text{\{the ball hits the fence % before it hits the ground\}}\big{)}=1-\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)-% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S).blackboard_P ( {the ball hits the fence before it hits the ground} ) = 1 - blackboard_P ( italic_R ) - blackboard_P ( italic_S ) .

In what follows, we determine the probabilities ‚Ñô‚Å°(R)‚ÑôùëÖ\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)blackboard_P ( italic_R ) and ‚Ñô‚Å°(S)‚ÑôùëÜ\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)blackboard_P ( italic_S ) using two different methods: the method of geometric probabilities (Method 1) and the law of total expectation (Method 2).

Method 1 (geometric probabilities): By Figure 3

and the method of geometric probabilities we obtain that

‚Ñô‚Å°(R)‚ÑôùëÖ\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)blackboard_P ( italic_R ) =‚Ñô‚Å°(d<10)=‚Ñô‚Å°(2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖv<10)=‚Ñô‚Å°(v<10‚Å¢g2‚ãÖ1h)absent‚Ñôùëë10‚Ñô‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëîùë£10‚Ñôùë£‚ãÖ10ùëî21‚Ñé\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(d<10\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb% {P}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot v<10\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(% v<\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{h}}\right)= blackboard_P ( italic_d < 10 ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ italic_v < 10 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_v < divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h end_ARG end_ARG )
=TR50‚Å¢(15‚àí5)=TR500,absentsubscriptùëáùëÖ50155subscriptùëáùëÖ500\displaystyle=\frac{T_{R}}{50(15-5)}=\frac{T_{R}}{500},= divide start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 50 ( 15 - 5 ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG ,

where 500500500500 is the area of the rectangle [0,50]√ó[5,15]050515[0,50]\times[5,15][ 0 , 50 ] √ó [ 5 , 15 ] (‚Äùtotal‚Äù area), and the ‚Äùprobable‚Äù area TRsubscriptùëáùëÖT_{R}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be calculated as follows. First, we determine the points at which the function (0,‚àû)‚àãh‚Ü¶10‚Å¢g2‚ãÖ1hcontains0‚Ñémaps-to‚ãÖ10ùëî21‚Ñé(0,\infty)\ni h\mapsto\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{h}}( 0 , ‚àû ) ‚àã italic_h ‚Ü¶ divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h end_ARG end_ARG takes the values 15151515 and 5555, respectively (see Figure 3). By algebraic calculations, we can get that

(2.2) the solution of the equation ¬†10‚Å¢g2‚ãÖ1h=15‚ãÖ10ùëî21‚Ñé15\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{h}}=15divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h end_ARG end_ARG = 15, h>0‚Ñé0h>0italic_h > 0, ¬†is ¬†h=g2‚ãÖ1.52=2.18‚Ñéùëî‚ãÖ2superscript1.522.18h=\frac{g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}=2.18italic_h = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ‚ãÖ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = 2.18,

and

TRsubscriptùëáùëÖ\displaystyle T_{R}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =‚à´0g2‚ãÖ1.52(15‚àí5)‚Å¢dp+‚à´g2‚ãÖ1.52g2‚ãÖ0.52(10‚Å¢g2‚ãÖ1p‚àí5)‚Å¢dpabsentsuperscriptsubscript0ùëî‚ãÖ2superscript1.52155differential-dùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëî‚ãÖ2superscript1.52ùëî‚ãÖ2superscript0.52‚ãÖ10ùëî21ùëù5differential-dùëù\displaystyle=\int_{0}^{\frac{g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}}(15-5)\,\mathrm{d}p+\int_{% \frac{g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}}^{\frac{g}{2\cdot 0.5^{2}}}\left(\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{% \sqrt{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{p}}-5\right)\,\mathrm{d}p= ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ‚ãÖ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 15 - 5 ) roman_d italic_p + ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ‚ãÖ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ‚ãÖ 0.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_p end_ARG end_ARG - 5 ) roman_d italic_p

Then

‚Ñô‚Å°(R)=20‚Å¢g3500=g75=0.1308.‚ÑôùëÖ20ùëî3500ùëî750.1308\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)=\frac{\frac{20g}{3}}{500}=\frac{g}{75}{=0.1308.}blackboard_P ( italic_R ) = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG 20 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 75 end_ARG = 0.1308 .

Similarly, we obtain

=‚Ñô‚Å°(v>10.5‚Å¢g2‚ãÖ1h‚àí2,h>2)=TS500,absent‚Ñôùë£‚ãÖ10.5ùëî21‚Ñé2‚Ñé2subscriptùëáùëÜ500\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(v>\frac{10.5\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}% \cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{h-2}},\,h>2\right)=\frac{T_{S}}{500},= blackboard_P ( italic_v > divide start_ARG 10.5 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h - 2 end_ARG end_ARG , italic_h > 2 ) = divide start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG ,

where the ‚Äùprobable‚Äù area TSsubscriptùëáùëÜT_{S}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be caclulated as follows. By algebraic calculations, we can get that

and

Consequently,

‚Ñô‚Å°(S)=480‚àí10.52‚Å¢g15500=4850‚àí110.25‚Å¢g7500‚âà0.8158.‚ÑôùëÜ480superscript10.52ùëî155004850110.25ùëî75000.8158\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)=\frac{480-\frac{10.5^{2}g}{15}}{500}=\frac{48}{50% }-\frac{110.25g}{7500}\approx 0.8158.blackboard_P ( italic_S ) = divide start_ARG 480 - divide start_ARG 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 15 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 48 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 110.25 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 7500 end_ARG ‚âà 0.8158 .

Method 2 (law of total expectation): Since vùë£vitalic_v is uniformly distributed on the interval [5,15]515[5,15][ 5 , 15 ], its density function takes the form

fv‚Å¢(r)={110if¬†r‚àà[5,15],0otherwise.subscriptùëìùë£ùëücases110if¬†r‚àà[5,15],0otherwise.f_{v}(r)=\begin{cases}\frac{1}{10}&\text{if \ $r\in[5,15]$,}\\ 0&\text{otherwise.}\end{cases}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) = { start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL if italic_r ‚àà [ 5 , 15 ] , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL otherwise. end_CELL end_ROW

Using the law of total expectation (see (A.4)) and the independence of h‚Ñéhitalic_h and vùë£vitalic_v, we have that

‚Ñô‚Å°(R)‚ÑôùëÖ\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)blackboard_P ( italic_R ) =‚Ñô‚Å°(d<10)=‚Ñô‚Å°(2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖv<10)=‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àû‚Ñô‚Å°(2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖr<10)‚Å¢fv‚Å¢(r)‚Å¢drabsent‚Ñôùëë10‚Ñô‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëîùë£10superscriptsubscript‚Ñô‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëîùëü10subscriptùëìùë£ùëüdifferential-dùëü\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<10)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(% \sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot v<10\right)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\operatorname{% \mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot r<10\right)f_{v}(r)\,\mathrm{d}r= blackboard_P ( italic_d < 10 ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ italic_v < 10 ) = ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ italic_r < 10 ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) roman_d italic_r
=‚à´515‚Ñô‚Å°(2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖr<10)‚Å¢110‚Å¢dr=110‚Å¢‚à´515‚Ñô‚Å°(h<100‚Å¢g2‚ãÖ1r2)‚Å¢dr,absentsuperscriptsubscript515‚Ñô‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëîùëü10110differential-dùëü110superscriptsubscript515‚Ñô‚Ñé‚ãÖ100ùëî21superscriptùëü2differential-dùëü\displaystyle=\int_{5}^{15}\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}% \cdot r<10\right)\frac{1}{10}\,\mathrm{d}r=\frac{1}{10}\int_{5}^{15}% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h<\frac{100g}{2}\cdot\frac{1}{r^{2}}\right)\,% \mathrm{d}r,= ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ italic_r < 10 ) divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG roman_d italic_r = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_h < divide start_ARG 100 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) roman_d italic_r ,

where

‚Ñô‚Å°(h<100‚Å¢g2‚ãÖ1r2)=150‚Å¢min‚Å°(50,50‚Å¢gr2)=150‚ãÖ50‚Å¢gr2=gr2,r‚àà[5,15],formulae-sequence‚Ñô‚Ñé‚ãÖ100ùëî21superscriptùëü21505050ùëîsuperscriptùëü2‚ãÖ15050ùëîsuperscriptùëü2ùëîsuperscriptùëü2ùëü515\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h<\frac{100g}{2}\cdot\frac{1}{r^{2}}\right)=% \frac{1}{50}\min\left(50,\frac{50g}{r^{2}}\right)=\frac{1}{50}\cdot\frac{50g}{% r^{2}}=\frac{g}{r^{2}},\qquad r\in[5,15],blackboard_P ( italic_h < divide start_ARG 100 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG roman_min ( 50 , divide start_ARG 50 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 50 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_r ‚àà [ 5 , 15 ] ,

since 50‚Å¢g/r2‚©Ω50‚Å¢g/25=19.6250ùëîsuperscriptùëü250ùëî2519.6250g/r^{2}\leqslant 50g/25=19.6250 italic_g / italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚©Ω 50 italic_g / 25 = 19.62. Consequently,

‚Ñô‚Å°(R)=110‚Å¢‚à´515gr2‚Å¢dr=g10‚Å¢(15‚àí115)=g75=0.1308.‚ÑôùëÖ110superscriptsubscript515ùëîsuperscriptùëü2differential-dùëüùëî1015115ùëî750.1308\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)=\frac{1}{10}\int_{5}^{15}\frac{g}{r^{2}}\,\mathrm% {d}r=\frac{g}{10}\left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{15}\right)=\frac{g}{75}=0.1308.blackboard_P ( italic_R ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_d italic_r = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 5 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 15 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 75 end_ARG = 0.1308 .

Similarly, using the law of total expectation (see (A.4)) and the independence of h‚Ñéhitalic_h and vùë£vitalic_v, we have that

‚Ñô‚Å°(S)‚ÑôùëÜ\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)blackboard_P ( italic_S ) =‚Ñô‚Å°(g2‚Å¢v2‚ãÖ10.52<h‚àí2)=‚Ñô‚Å°(h>2+g2‚Å¢v2‚ãÖ10.52)absent‚Ñô‚ãÖùëî2superscriptùë£2superscript10.52‚Ñé2‚Ñô‚Ñé2‚ãÖùëî2superscriptùë£2superscript10.52\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\frac{g}{2v^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{2}<h-% 2\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h>2+\frac{g}{2v^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{2}\right)= blackboard_P ( divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚ãÖ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_h - 2 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h > 2 + divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚ãÖ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )

where 50‚àí(2+g2‚Å¢r2‚ãÖ10.52)‚©æ0502‚ãÖùëî2superscriptùëü2superscript10.52050-\Big{(}2+\frac{g}{2r^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{2}\Big{)}\geqslant 050 - ( 2 + divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚ãÖ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚©æ 0 for all r‚àà[5,15]ùëü515r\in[5,15]italic_r ‚àà [ 5 , 15 ], since it holds if and only if r2‚©æ10.52‚Å¢g/96‚âà11.27superscriptùëü2superscript10.52ùëî9611.27r^{2}\geqslant 10.5^{2}g/96\approx 11.27italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚©æ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_g / 96 ‚âà 11.27, which is true since r‚©æ5ùëü5r\geqslant 5italic_r ‚©æ 5. Hence we get that

‚Ñô‚Å°(S)‚ÑôùëÜ\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)blackboard_P ( italic_S ) =1500‚Å¢‚à´515(48‚àíg2‚Å¢r2‚ãÖ10.52)‚Å¢drabsent1500superscriptsubscript51548‚ãÖùëî2superscriptùëü2superscript10.52differential-dùëü\displaystyle=\frac{1}{500}\int_{5}^{15}\Big{(}48-\frac{g}{2r^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{% 2}\Big{)}\,\mathrm{d}r= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 48 - divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚ãÖ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_r
=1500‚Å¢(48‚Å¢(15‚àí5)+10.52‚Å¢g2‚Å¢(115‚àí15))=4850‚àí110.25‚Å¢g7500‚âà0.8158.absent150048155superscript10.52ùëî2115154850110.25ùëî75000.8158\displaystyle=\frac{1}{500}\Big{(}48(15-5)+\frac{10.5^{2}g}{2}\Big{(}\frac{1}{% 15}-\frac{1}{5}\Big{)}\Big{)}=\frac{48}{50}-\frac{110.25g}{7500}\approx 0.8158.= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG ( 48 ( 15 - 5 ) + divide start_ARG 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 15 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 5 end_ARG ) ) = divide start_ARG 48 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 110.25 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 7500 end_ARG ‚âà 0.8158 .

Note that we calculated the same value for ‚Ñô‚Å°(S)‚ÑôùëÜ\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)blackboard_P ( italic_S ) using Methods 1 and 2, as it was expected.

Using the values of ‚Ñô‚Å°(R)‚ÑôùëÖ\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)blackboard_P ( italic_R ) and ‚Ñô‚Å°(S)‚ÑôùëÜ\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)blackboard_P ( italic_S ), (2.1) implies that

1‚àí‚Ñô‚Å°(R)‚àí‚Ñô‚Å°(S)=1‚àíg75‚àí4850+110.25‚Å¢g7500=250+(110.257500‚àí175)‚Å¢g‚âà0.05341.1‚ÑôùëÖ‚ÑôùëÜ1ùëî754850110.25ùëî7500250110.257500175ùëî0.05341\displaystyle 1-\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)-\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)=1-% \frac{g}{75}-\frac{48}{50}+\frac{110.25g}{7500}=\frac{2}{50}+\left(\frac{110.2% 5}{7500}-\frac{1}{75}\right)g\approx 0.05341.1 - blackboard_P ( italic_R ) - blackboard_P ( italic_S ) = 1 - divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 75 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 48 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 110.25 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 7500 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG + ( divide start_ARG 110.25 end_ARG start_ARG 7500 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 75 end_ARG ) italic_g ‚âà 0.05341 .

(iii). We have to calculate the conditional probability ‚Ñô‚Å°(h‚Å¢<10|‚Å¢d<10)‚Ñô‚Ñébra10ùëë10\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10\,|\,d<10)blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 | italic_d < 10 ). ‚Ñô‚Å°(h‚Å¢<10|‚Å¢d<10)=‚Ñô‚Å°(h<10,d<10)‚Ñô‚Å°(d<10)=75g‚Å¢‚Ñô‚Å°(h<10,d<10).‚Ñô‚Ñébra10ùëë10‚Ñô‚Ñé10ùëë10‚Ñôùëë1075ùëî‚Ñô‚Ñé10ùëë10\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10\,|\,d<10)=\frac{\operatorname{% \mathbb{P}}(h<10,d<10)}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<10)}=\frac{75}{g}% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10,d<10).blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 | italic_d < 10 ) = divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , italic_d < 10 ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_d < 10 ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG 75 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , italic_d < 10 ) .

Using Figure 5

and the method of geometric probabilities, we get that

‚Ñô‚Å°(h<10,d<10)‚Ñô‚Ñé10ùëë10\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10,d<10)blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , italic_d < 10 ) =‚Ñô‚Å°(h<10,2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖv<10)=‚Ñô‚Å°(h<10,v<10‚Å¢g2‚ãÖ1h)absent‚Ñô‚Ñé10‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëîùë£10‚Ñô‚Ñé10ùë£‚ãÖ10ùëî21‚Ñé\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h<10,\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot v<1% 0\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h<10,v<\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}% \cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{h}}\right)= blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ italic_v < 10 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , italic_v < divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h end_ARG end_ARG )
=T50‚Å¢(15‚àí5)=T500,absentùëá50155ùëá500\displaystyle=\frac{T}{50(15-5)}=\frac{T}{500},= divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 50 ( 15 - 5 ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG ,

where 500500500500 is the area of the rectangle [0,50]√ó[5,15]050515[0,50]\times[5,15][ 0 , 50 ] √ó [ 5 , 15 ] (‚Äùtotal‚Äù area), and the ‚Äùprobable‚Äù area TùëáTitalic_T can be calculated as follows. Using (2.2) and (2.3), we have that

Tùëá\displaystyle Titalic_T =‚à´0g2‚ãÖ1.52(15‚àí5)‚Å¢dp+‚à´g2‚ãÖ1.5210(10‚Å¢g2‚ãÖ1p‚àí5)‚Å¢dpabsentsuperscriptsubscript0ùëî‚ãÖ2superscript1.52155differential-dùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëî‚ãÖ2superscript1.5210‚ãÖ10ùëî21ùëù5differential-dùëù\displaystyle=\int_{0}^{\frac{g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}}(15-5)\,\mathrm{d}p+\int_{% \frac{g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}}^{10}\left(\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{% \sqrt{p}}-5\right)\,\mathrm{d}p= ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ‚ãÖ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 15 - 5 ) roman_d italic_p + ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ‚ãÖ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_p end_ARG end_ARG - 5 ) roman_d italic_p
=10‚Å¢g2‚ãÖ1.52+10‚Å¢2‚Å¢g‚Å¢(10‚àíg1.5‚Å¢2)‚àí5‚Å¢(10‚àíg2‚ãÖ1.52)absent10ùëî‚ãÖ2superscript1.52102ùëî10ùëî1.52510ùëî‚ãÖ2superscript1.52\displaystyle=\frac{10g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}+10\sqrt{2g}\left(\sqrt{10}-\frac{% \sqrt{g}}{1.5\sqrt{2}}\right)-5\left(10-\frac{g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}\right)= divide start_ARG 10 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ‚ãÖ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + 10 square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG ( square-root start_ARG 10 end_ARG - divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 1.5 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ) - 5 ( 10 - divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ‚ãÖ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG )
=10‚Å¢g4.5+10‚Å¢20‚Å¢g‚àí10‚Å¢g1.5‚àí50+5‚Å¢g4.5absent10ùëî4.51020ùëî10ùëî1.5505ùëî4.5\displaystyle=\frac{10g}{4.5}+10\sqrt{20g}-\frac{10g}{1.5}-50+\frac{5g}{4.5}= divide start_ARG 10 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 4.5 end_ARG + 10 square-root start_ARG 20 italic_g end_ARG - divide start_ARG 10 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 1.5 end_ARG - 50 + divide start_ARG 5 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 4.5 end_ARG
=‚àí15‚Å¢g4.5+10‚Å¢20‚Å¢g‚àí50.absent15ùëî4.51020ùëî50\displaystyle=-\frac{15g}{4.5}+10\sqrt{20g}-50.= - divide start_ARG 15 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 4.5 end_ARG + 10 square-root start_ARG 20 italic_g end_ARG - 50 .

We remark that the probability ‚Ñô‚Å°(h<10,d<10)‚Ñô‚Ñé10ùëë10\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10,d<10)blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , italic_d < 10 ) could be determined using the law of total expectation as well similarly as in the solution of part (ii) (by Method 2), but we will leave it for now.

All in all, we get that

‚Ñô‚Å°(h‚Å¢<10|‚Å¢d<10)=75500‚Å¢(‚àí154.5+10‚Å¢20g‚àí50g)‚âà0.8772.‚Ñô‚Ñébra10ùëë1075500154.51020ùëî50ùëî0.8772\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10\,|\,d<10)=\frac{75}{500}\left(-% \frac{15}{4.5}+\frac{10\sqrt{20}}{\sqrt{g}}-\frac{50}{g}\right)\approx 0.8772.blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 | italic_d < 10 ) = divide start_ARG 75 end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG ( - divide start_ARG 15 end_ARG start_ARG 4.5 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG 20 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG - divide start_ARG 50 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ) ‚âà 0.8772 .

‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

We note that students may formulate and solve a natural counterpart of Exercise 2.1 by choosing the height (where Thomas stops) according to a (discrete) uniform distribution, for example, on the finite set {1‚Å¢m,2‚Å¢m,‚Ä¶,49‚Å¢m,50‚Å¢m}1m2m‚Ä¶49m50m\{1\,\mathrm{m},2\,\mathrm{m},\ldots,49\,\mathrm{m},50\,\mathrm{m}\}{ 1 roman_m , 2 roman_m , ‚Ä¶ , 49 roman_m , 50 roman_m }. Of course, one could also consider other discrete or absolutely continuous distributions with range in [0,50]050[0,50][ 0 , 50 ]. For example, the discrete distribution on the set {10‚Å¢m,20‚Å¢m,30‚Å¢m,40‚Å¢m,50‚Å¢m}10m20m30m40m50m\{10\,\mathrm{m},20\,\mathrm{m},30\,\mathrm{m},40\,\mathrm{m},50\,\mathrm{m}\}{ 10 roman_m , 20 roman_m , 30 roman_m , 40 roman_m , 50 roman_m } with corresponding probabilities 40100,30100,20100,9100,110040100301002010091001100\frac{40}{100},\frac{30}{100},\frac{20}{100},\frac{9}{100},\frac{1}{100}divide start_ARG 40 end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG , divide start_ARG 30 end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG , divide start_ARG 20 end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG , divide start_ARG 9 end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG would may suggest that Thomas has a fear of heights.

2.2 Exercise.

Let us consider a rectangular cuboid-shape building with a height of 50 meters, standing on horizontal ground. From the bottom of the building, Anne takes the elevator up. Anne stops at a height h‚Ñéhitalic_h chosen according to a uniform distribution on the interval [0‚Å¢m,50‚Å¢m]0m50m[0\,\mathrm{m},50\,\mathrm{m}][ 0 roman_m , 50 roman_m ], and from the edge of the building she throws a ball with velocity vùë£vitalic_v of which the magnitude is 151515\,15msms\mathrm{\frac{m}{s}}divide start_ARG roman_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_s end_ARG and its direction is perpendicular to the wall of the building. Parallel to Anne‚Äôs building, there is another rectangular cuboid-shape building, 15 metres away, its height is 50505050 meters. If the thrown ball reaches the opposite house, then it bounces back elastically from its wall, and if the rebounced ball also reaches the wall of Anne‚Äôs house, then it rebounces (elastically) from it as well, and so on.

  • (i)

    What is the distribution of the number of times the ball rebounces before it hits the ground?

  • (ii)

    What is the expectation, variance and relative standard deviation of the number of times the ball rebounces before it hits the ground?

  • (iii)

    What is the probability that the ball hits the ground closer to Anne‚Äôs building?

Solution. (i). It is known that if we launch a ball horizontally at height h‚Ñéhitalic_h with velocity vùë£vitalic_v, then the total (horizontal) distance of the whole journey before the ball hits the ground is d:=2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖvassignùëë‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëîùë£d:=\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot vitalic_d := square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ italic_v.

Since we assumed that the rebounds (collisions) are elastic, the trajectory after the first collision (provided that such a collision occurs) is the reflection of the imaginary continuation of the trajectory before the first collision after the colliding surface (wall) on the colliding surface. Similarly, the trajectory after the second collision (provided that such a collision occurs) is the reflection of the imaginary continuation of the trajectory after the first collision after the second colliding surface on the (second) colliding surface. This train of thought can be continued in a similar way for all of the collisions that occur. Consequently, it is enough to consider a single projectile motion, launched at height h‚Ñéhitalic_h with horizontal velocity vùë£vitalic_v.

Let the random variable Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ denote the number of times the ball rebounces before it hits the ground.

For all nonnegative integer kùëòkitalic_k, we have that

{Œæ=k}={¬†the distance¬†d¬†traveled horizontally by the ball before it hits the ground\displaystyle\{\xi=k\}=\Big{\{}\text{ the distance $d$ traveled horizontally % by the ball before it hits the ground}{ italic_Œæ = italic_k } = { the distance italic_d traveled horizontally by the ball before it hits the ground
¬†is in¬†[15‚Å¢k,15‚Å¢(k+1))¬†}.\displaystyle\phantom{\{\xi=k\}=\Big{\{}\,}\text{ is in $[15k,15(k+1))$ }\Big{% \}}.is in [ 15 italic_k , 15 ( italic_k + 1 ) ) } .

Since the maximum value of dùëëditalic_d is 2‚ãÖ50g‚ãÖ15‚âà47.89‚ãÖ‚ãÖ250ùëî1547.89\sqrt{\frac{2\cdot 50}{g}}\cdot 15\approx 47.89square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ‚ãÖ 50 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ 15 ‚âà 47.89, the ball can rebound maximum three times. Hence the range of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ is {0,1,2,3}0123\{0,1,2,3\}{ 0 , 1 , 2 , 3 }, and, using that h‚Ñéhitalic_h is a uniformly distributed random variable on the interval [0,50]050[0,50][ 0 , 50 ], we get that

‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=0)=‚Ñô‚Å°(d<15)=‚Ñô‚Å°(2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖ15<15)=‚Ñô‚Å°(h<g/2)=g/250=g100,‚Ñôùúâ0‚Ñôùëë15‚Ñô‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëî1515‚Ñô‚Ñéùëî2ùëî250ùëî100\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=0)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<15)=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot 15<15\right)=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<g/2)=\frac{g/2}{50}=\frac{g}{100},blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 0 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_d < 15 ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ 15 < 15 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h < italic_g / 2 ) = divide start_ARG italic_g / 2 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ,
‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=1)=‚Ñô‚Å°(15‚©Ωd<30)=‚Ñô‚Å°(15‚©Ω2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖ15<30)=‚Ñô‚Å°(g2‚©Ωh<4‚Å¢g2)=3‚Å¢g100,‚Ñôùúâ1‚Ñô15ùëë30‚Ñô15‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëî1530‚Ñôùëî2‚Ñé4ùëî23ùëî100\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=1)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(15% \leqslant d<30)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(15\leqslant\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}% \cdot 15<30\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\frac{g}{2}\leqslant h<\frac% {4g}{2}\right)=\frac{3g}{100},blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 1 ) = blackboard_P ( 15 ‚©Ω italic_d < 30 ) = blackboard_P ( 15 ‚©Ω square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ 15 < 30 ) = blackboard_P ( divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚©Ω italic_h < divide start_ARG 4 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 3 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ,
‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=2)=‚Ñô‚Å°(30‚©Ωd<45)=‚Ñô‚Å°(30‚©Ω2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖ15<45)=‚Ñô‚Å°(4‚Å¢g2‚©Ωh<9‚Å¢g2)=5‚Å¢g100,‚Ñôùúâ2‚Ñô30ùëë45‚Ñô30‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëî1545‚Ñô4ùëî2‚Ñé9ùëî25ùëî100\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(30% \leqslant d<45)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(30\leqslant\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}% \cdot 15<45\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\frac{4g}{2}\leqslant h<% \frac{9g}{2}\right)=\frac{5g}{100},blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 2 ) = blackboard_P ( 30 ‚©Ω italic_d < 45 ) = blackboard_P ( 30 ‚©Ω square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ 15 < 45 ) = blackboard_P ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚©Ω italic_h < divide start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 5 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ,
‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=3)=‚Ñô‚Å°(45‚©Ωd<65)=1‚àí‚Ñô‚Å°(d<45)=1‚àí(‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=0)+‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=1)+‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=2))‚Ñôùúâ3‚Ñô45ùëë651‚Ñôùëë451‚Ñôùúâ0‚Ñôùúâ1‚Ñôùúâ2\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=3)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(45% \leqslant d<65)=1-\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<45)=1-(\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}% (\xi=0)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=1)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2))blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 3 ) = blackboard_P ( 45 ‚©Ω italic_d < 65 ) = 1 - blackboard_P ( italic_d < 45 ) = 1 - ( blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 0 ) + blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 1 ) + blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 2 ) )
=1‚àí9‚Å¢g100.absent19ùëî100\displaystyle\phantom{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=3)}=1-\frac{9g}{100}.= 1 - divide start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG .

(ii). The expected value of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ takes the form

ùîº‚Å°(Œæ)ùîºùúâ\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) =‚àëk=03k‚Å¢‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=k)=1‚ãÖ3‚Å¢g100+2‚ãÖ5‚Å¢g100+3‚ãÖ100‚àí9‚Å¢g100=3‚Å¢g+10‚Å¢g+300‚àí27‚Å¢g100absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëò03ùëò‚Ñôùúâùëò‚ãÖ13ùëî100‚ãÖ25ùëî100‚ãÖ31009ùëî1003ùëî10ùëî30027ùëî100\displaystyle=\sum_{k=0}^{3}k\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=k)=1\cdot\frac{3g}{% 100}+2\cdot\frac{5g}{100}+3\cdot\frac{100-9g}{100}=\frac{3g+10g+300-27g}{100}= ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = italic_k ) = 1 ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 3 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG + 2 ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 5 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG + 3 ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 100 - 9 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 3 italic_g + 10 italic_g + 300 - 27 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG
=300‚àí14‚Å¢g100‚âà1.627.absent30014ùëî1001.627\displaystyle=\frac{300-14g}{100}\approx 1.627.= divide start_ARG 300 - 14 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ‚âà 1.627 .

Now, we turn to calculate the variance and standard deviation of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ. We have that

and hence the standard deviation of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ is

This implies that the relative standard deviation of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ is

RSD‚Å°(Œæ)=650‚Å¢g‚àí49‚Å¢g250300‚àí14‚Å¢g100=650‚Å¢g‚àí49‚Å¢g2150‚àí7‚Å¢g‚âà0.5011.RSDùúâ650ùëî49superscriptùëî25030014ùëî100650ùëî49superscriptùëî21507ùëî0.5011\operatorname{RSD}(\xi)=\frac{\frac{\sqrt{650g-49g^{2}}}{50}}{\frac{300-14g}{1% 00}}=\frac{\sqrt{650g-49g^{2}}}{150-7g}\approx 0.5011.roman_RSD ( italic_Œæ ) = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 650 italic_g - 49 italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG 300 - 14 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG end_ARG = divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 650 italic_g - 49 italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 150 - 7 italic_g end_ARG ‚âà 0.5011 .

(iii). Let Aùê¥Aitalic_A be the event that the ball hits the ground closer to Anne‚Äôs building. Using the additivity of probability and that the maximum value of dùëëditalic_d is 2‚ãÖ50g‚ãÖ15‚âà47.89‚ãÖ‚ãÖ250ùëî1547.89\sqrt{\frac{2\cdot 50}{g}}\cdot 15\approx 47.89square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ‚ãÖ 50 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ 15 ‚âà 47.89 (see part (i)), we get that

‚Ñô‚Å°(A)‚Ñôùê¥\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)blackboard_P ( italic_A ) =‚àëk=03‚Ñô‚Å°(A,Œæ=k)absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëò03‚Ñôùê¥ùúâùëò\displaystyle=\sum_{k=0}^{3}\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A,\xi=k)= ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_A , italic_Œæ = italic_k )
=‚Ñô‚Å°(d<7.5)+‚Ñô‚Å°(15+7.5‚©Ωd<15+15)+‚Ñô‚Å°(30‚©Ωd‚©Ω30+7.5)absent‚Ñôùëë7.5‚Ñô157.5ùëë1515‚Ñô30ùëë307.5\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<7.5)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(15+7.% 5\leqslant d<15+15)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(30\leqslant d\leqslant 30+7.5)= blackboard_P ( italic_d < 7.5 ) + blackboard_P ( 15 + 7.5 ‚©Ω italic_d < 15 + 15 ) + blackboard_P ( 30 ‚©Ω italic_d ‚©Ω 30 + 7.5 )
+‚Ñô‚Å°(45+7.5‚©Ωd<45+15)‚Ñô457.5ùëë4515\displaystyle\phantom{=\;}+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(45+7.5\leqslant d<45+15)+ blackboard_P ( 45 + 7.5 ‚©Ω italic_d < 45 + 15 )
=‚Ñô‚Å°(d<7.5)+‚Ñô‚Å°(22.5‚©Ωd<37.5)+0absent‚Ñôùëë7.5‚Ñô22.5ùëë37.50\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<7.5)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(22.5% \leqslant d<37.5)+0= blackboard_P ( italic_d < 7.5 ) + blackboard_P ( 22.5 ‚©Ω italic_d < 37.5 ) + 0
=‚Ñô‚Å°(2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖ15<7.5)+‚Ñô‚Å°(22.5‚©Ω2‚Å¢hg‚ãÖ15<37.5)absent‚Ñô‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëî157.5‚Ñô22.5‚ãÖ2‚Ñéùëî1537.5\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot 15<7.5% \right)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(22.5\leqslant\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot 1% 5<37.5\right)= blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ 15 < 7.5 ) + blackboard_P ( 22.5 ‚©Ω square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ 15 < 37.5 )
=‚Ñô‚Å°(h‚©Ωg8)+‚Ñô‚Å°(9‚Å¢g8‚©Ωh<25‚Å¢g8)=150‚Å¢(g8+(25‚àí9)‚Å¢g8)=17‚Å¢g400‚âà0.4169.absent‚Ñô‚Ñéùëî8‚Ñô9ùëî8‚Ñé25ùëî8150ùëî8259ùëî817ùëî4000.4169\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h\leqslant\frac{g}{8}\right)+% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\frac{9g}{8}\leqslant h<\frac{25g}{8}\right)=% \frac{1}{50}\left(\frac{g}{8}+\frac{(25-9)g}{8}\right)=\frac{17g}{400}\approx 0% .4169.= blackboard_P ( italic_h ‚©Ω divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ) + blackboard_P ( divide start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ‚©Ω italic_h < divide start_ARG 25 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG + divide start_ARG ( 25 - 9 ) italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 17 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 400 end_ARG ‚âà 0.4169 .

‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

Part (i) of the next Exercise 2.3 is a randomized version of Exercise 2 for 4-th grade high school students at the √Ågoston Bud√≥ Physics Competition (1980) (see [6]) in the sense that we randomly choose the height from which we drop the ball. Parts (ii), (iii) and (iv) of Exercise 2.3 contain new probabilistic-type questions to the same phenomena.

2.3 Exercise.

From a height chosen uniformly distributed between 00 and 1111 meters, we drop a ball on the table. We assume that the ball loses 5%percent55\%5 % of its velocity by each collision with the table.

  • (i)

    What is the density function, expectation, variance and relative standard deviation of the total time (in seconds) that elapses before the ball stops moving?

  • (ii)

    What is the density function, expectation, variance and relative standard deviation of the total distance (in meters) that the ball travels during its motion?

  • (iii)

    What is the probability that the ball ends its movement earlier than an identical ball dropped on the table from a height of 0.50.50.50.5 meters? Calculate the same probability if 0.50.50.50.5 meters is replaced by 4949\frac{4}{9}divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG meters! What could be the reason for choosing 4949\frac{4}{9}divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG meters in the previous task?

  • (iv)

    Let Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ denote a random variable that counts the number of times the ball is at a height of 0.10.10.10.1 meter during its movement. Let us determine the distribution and expectation of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ!

Solution. Let h0subscript‚Ñé0h_{0}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the number of metres from which the ball is dropped. Then h0subscript‚Ñé0h_{0}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is uniformly distributed on the interval [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ]. Let us introduce the following notations: for each nonnegative integer nùëõnitalic_n, let vn+1:=0.95‚Å¢vnassignsubscriptùë£ùëõ10.95subscriptùë£ùëõv_{n+1}:=0.95\,v_{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := 0.95 italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where v0subscriptùë£0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the velocity of a ball dropped from a height of h0subscript‚Ñé0h_{0}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when it hits the ground. The movement that takes place (bouncing) is an infinite sequence of consecutive free falls and vertical upward projectile motions. A ball dropped from a height of h0subscript‚Ñé0h_{0}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT takes time t0:=2‚Å¢h0gassignsubscriptùë°02subscript‚Ñé0ùëît_{0}:=\sqrt{\frac{2h_{0}}{g}}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG to hit the ground, and then its velocity is v0=g‚Å¢t0=2‚Å¢g‚Å¢h0subscriptùë£0ùëîsubscriptùë°02ùëîsubscript‚Ñé0v_{0}=gt_{0}=\sqrt{2gh_{0}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_g italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG.

By the assumption, the initial velocity of the vertical upward projectile motion after the first bounce is v1=0.95‚Å¢v0subscriptùë£10.95subscriptùë£0v_{1}=0.95\,v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.95 italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It is known that the time to reach the maximum height is t1:=v1gassignsubscriptùë°1subscriptùë£1ùëît_{1}:=\frac{v_{1}}{g}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG and the maximum height of the projectile motion in question is v122‚Å¢gsuperscriptsubscriptùë£122ùëî\frac{v_{1}^{2}}{2g}divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG. The new (second) fall time is t1‚Ä≤:=t1assignsuperscriptsubscriptùë°1‚Ä≤subscriptùë°1t_{1}^{\prime}:=t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, since there is no energy loss, and the velocity at the (second) landing is 2‚Å¢g‚Å¢v122‚Å¢g=v12ùëîsuperscriptsubscriptùë£122ùëîsubscriptùë£1\sqrt{2g\frac{v_{1}^{2}}{2g}}=v_{1}square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG end_ARG = italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (that is, it is equal to the initial velocity of the vertical upward projectile motion after the first rebounce).

Similarly, for the vertical upward projectile motion after the second rebounce, by the assumption, we have that its initial velocity is v2=0.95‚Å¢v1=0.952‚Å¢v0subscriptùë£20.95subscriptùë£1superscript0.952subscriptùë£0v_{2}=0.95v_{1}=0.95^{2}v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.95 italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the time to reach its maximum height is t1:=v1gassignsubscriptùë°1subscriptùë£1ùëît_{1}:=\frac{v_{1}}{g}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG, its maximum height is v222‚Å¢gsuperscriptsubscriptùë£222ùëî\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{2g}divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG, and its fall time is t2‚Ä≤:=t2assignsuperscriptsubscriptùë°2‚Ä≤subscriptùë°2t_{2}^{\prime}:=t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, since there is no energy loss.

By induction, for the vertical upward projectile motion after the nthsuperscriptùëõthn^{\mathrm{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT rebounce, by the assumption, we have that its initial velocity is vn=0.95n‚Å¢v0subscriptùë£ùëõsuperscript0.95ùëõsubscriptùë£0v_{n}=0.95^{n}v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the time to reach its maximum height is tn:=vng=0.95n‚Å¢v0gassignsubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùë£ùëõùëîsuperscript0.95ùëõsubscriptùë£0ùëît_{n}:=\frac{v_{n}}{g}=\frac{0.95^{n}v_{0}}{g}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG = divide start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG, its maximum height is vn22‚Å¢gsuperscriptsubscriptùë£ùëõ22ùëî\frac{v_{n}^{2}}{2g}divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG, and its fall time is tn‚Ä≤:=tnassignsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëõ‚Ä≤subscriptùë°ùëõt_{n}^{\prime}:=t_{n}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, since there is no energy loss.

Consequently, the total time that elapses before the ball stops moving is

t:=t0+t1+t1‚Ä≤+t2+t2‚Ä≤+‚ãØ=t0+‚àën=1‚àû(tn+tn‚Ä≤)=t0+2‚Å¢‚àën=1‚àûtn,assignùë°subscriptùë°0subscriptùë°1superscriptsubscriptùë°1‚Ä≤subscriptùë°2superscriptsubscriptùë°2‚Ä≤‚ãØsubscriptùë°0superscriptsubscriptùëõ1subscriptùë°ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëõ‚Ä≤subscriptùë°02superscriptsubscriptùëõ1subscriptùë°ùëõ\displaystyle t:=t_{0}+t_{1}+t_{1}^{\prime}+t_{2}+t_{2}^{\prime}+\cdots=t_{0}+% \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(t_{n}+t_{n}^{\prime})=t_{0}+2\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}t_{n},italic_t := italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ‚ãØ = italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Ä≤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

and the total distance that the ball travels during its motion is

Using these two formulas, we get that

(i). First, we determine the cumulative distribution function of tùë°titalic_t. Consequently, the cumulative distribution function Ft:‚Ñù‚Üí[0,1]:subscriptùêπùë°‚Üí‚Ñù01F_{t}:\mathbb{R}\to[0,1]italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R ‚Üí [ 0 , 1 ] of tùë°titalic_t takes the form

This implies that the density function ft:‚Ñù‚Üí[0,‚àû):subscriptùëìùë°‚Üí‚Ñù0f_{t}:\mathbb{R}\to[0,\infty)italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R ‚Üí [ 0 , ‚àû ) of tùë°titalic_t takes the form

The expected value of the total time tùë°titalic_t that elapses before the ball stops moving is

ùîº‚Å°(t)=39‚Å¢2g‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(h0)=39‚Å¢2g‚Å¢‚à´01x‚Å¢dx=39‚Å¢2g‚ãÖ23‚âà11.74.ùîºùë°392ùëîùîºsubscript‚Ñé0392ùëîsuperscriptsubscript01ùë•differential-dùë•‚ãÖ392ùëî2311.74\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(t)=39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\operatorname{% \mathbb{E}}(\sqrt{h_{0}})=39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\int_{0}^{1}\sqrt{x}\,\mathrm{d}% x=39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\cdot\frac{2}{3}\approx 11.74.blackboard_E ( italic_t ) = 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG blackboard_E ( square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) = 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_x end_ARG roman_d italic_x = 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ‚âà 11.74 .

Alternatively, we can also calculate the expected value of tùë°titalic_t using its density function ftsubscriptùëìùë°f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as follows:

ùîº‚Å°(t)=‚à´039‚Å¢2gx‚ãÖg1521‚Å¢x‚Å¢dx=g1521‚ãÖ(39‚Å¢2g)33=39‚Å¢2g‚ãÖ23.ùîºùë°superscriptsubscript0392ùëî‚ãÖùë•ùëî1521ùë•differential-dùë•‚ãÖùëî1521superscript392ùëî33‚ãÖ392ùëî23\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(t)=\int_{0}^{39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}}x% \cdot\frac{g}{1521}x\,\mathrm{d}x=\frac{g}{1521}\cdot\frac{\left(39\sqrt{\frac% {2}{g}}\right)^{3}}{3}=39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\cdot\frac{2}{3}.blackboard_E ( italic_t ) = ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 1521 end_ARG italic_x roman_d italic_x = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 1521 end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG ( 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG = 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG .

We call the attention to the fact that ùîº‚Å°(t)ùîºùë°\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(t)blackboard_E ( italic_t ) is not equal to the total time that elapses before a ball dropped from a height of 0.50.50.50.5 meters stops moving (39‚Å¢2g‚Å¢0.5‚âà12.45)392ùëî0.512.45\Big{(}39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\sqrt{0.5}\approx 12.45\Big{)}( 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG 0.5 end_ARG ‚âà 12.45 ), but it is equal to the total time that elapses before a ball dropped from a height of 4949\frac{4}{9}divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG stops moving.

Now, we turn to calculate the variance and standard deviation of tùë°titalic_t. We have that

ùîº‚Å°(t2)=392‚ãÖ2g‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(h0)=392‚ãÖ2g‚ãÖ12=392g,ùîºsuperscriptùë°2‚ãÖsuperscript3922ùëîùîºsubscript‚Ñé0‚ãÖsuperscript3922ùëî12superscript392ùëî\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(t^{2})=39^{2}\cdot\frac{2}{g}% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(h_{0})=39^{2}\cdot\frac{2}{g}\cdot\frac{1}{2}=\frac{% 39^{2}}{g},blackboard_E ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG blackboard_E ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ,

and hence the variance and standard deviation of tùë°titalic_t take the following forms

ùîª2‚Å°(t)=392g‚àí392‚ãÖ2g‚ãÖ49=3929‚Å¢g‚âà17.23,superscriptùîª2ùë°superscript392ùëî‚ãÖsuperscript3922ùëî49superscript3929ùëî17.23\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}^{2}(t)=\frac{39^{2}}{g}-39^{2}\cdot\frac{2}{g}\cdot% \frac{4}{9}=\frac{39^{2}}{9g}\approx 17.23,blackboard_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = divide start_ARG 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG - 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG ‚âà 17.23 ,

and

ùîª‚Å°(t)=3929‚Å¢g.ùîªùë°superscript3929ùëî\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}(t)=\sqrt{\frac{39^{2}}{9g}}.blackboard_D ( italic_t ) = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG end_ARG .

This implies that the relative standard deviation of tùë°titalic_t is

RSD‚Å°(t)=393‚Å¢g39‚Å¢2g‚ãÖ23=12‚Å¢2‚âà0.3536.RSDùë°393ùëî‚ãÖ392ùëî231220.3536\operatorname{RSD}(t)=\frac{\frac{39}{3\sqrt{g}}}{39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\cdot% \frac{2}{3}}=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{2}}\approx 0.3536.roman_RSD ( italic_t ) = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG 39 end_ARG start_ARG 3 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ‚âà 0.3536 .

(ii). The expected value of the total distance sùë†sitalic_s that the ball travels during its motion is

Note that ùîº‚Å°(s)ùîºùë†\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(s)blackboard_E ( italic_s ) is equal to the total distance that a ball dropped from a height of 0.50.50.50.5 meters travels during its motion.

Now, we turn to calculate the variance and standard deviation of sùë†sitalic_s. We have that

ùîº‚Å°(s2)=‚à´0761/39x2‚ãÖ39761‚Å¢dx=39761‚ãÖ13‚Å¢(76139)3=13‚Å¢(76139)2,ùîºsuperscriptùë†2superscriptsubscript076139‚ãÖsuperscriptùë•239761differential-dùë•‚ãÖ3976113superscript76139313superscript761392\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(s^{2})=\int_{0}^{761/39}x^{2}\cdot\frac% {39}{761}\,\mathrm{d}x=\frac{39}{761}\cdot\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{761}{39}% \right)^{3}=\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{761}{39}\right)^{2},blackboard_E ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 761 / 39 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 39 end_ARG start_ARG 761 end_ARG roman_d italic_x = divide start_ARG 39 end_ARG start_ARG 761 end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

and hence the variance and standard deviation of sùë†sitalic_s take the following forms

ùîª2‚Å°(s)=13‚Å¢(76139)2‚àí(76178)2=112‚Å¢(76139)2‚âà31.73,superscriptùîª2ùë†13superscript761392superscript761782112superscript76139231.73\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}^{2}(s)=\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{761}{39}\right)^{2}-% \left(\frac{761}{78}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{12}\left(\frac{761}{39}\right)^{2}% \approx 31.73,blackboard_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 78 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 12 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚âà 31.73 ,

and

This implies that the relative standard deviation of sùë†sitalic_s is

Since the relative standard deviation of sùë†sitalic_s is greater than that of tùë°titalic_t, roughly speaking, one can say that the level of dispersion of the values of sùë†sitalic_s around it mean ùîº‚Å°(s)ùîºùë†\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(s)blackboard_E ( italic_s ) is greater than that of the values of tùë°titalic_t around its mean ùîº‚Å°(t)ùîºùë°\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(t)blackboard_E ( italic_t ).

(iii). Then we have that

‚Ñô‚Å°(39‚Å¢2g‚Å¢h0<39‚Å¢2g‚Å¢0.5)=‚Ñô‚Å°(h0<0.5)=‚Ñô‚Å°(h0<0.5)=12,‚Ñô392ùëîsubscript‚Ñé0392ùëî0.5‚Ñôsubscript‚Ñé00.5‚Ñôsubscript‚Ñé00.512\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\sqrt{h_{0}}<39\sqrt{\frac% {2}{g}}\sqrt{0.5}\Big{)}=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\sqrt{h_{0}}<\sqrt{0.5})=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h_{0}<0.5)=\frac{1}{2},blackboard_P ( 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG < 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG 0.5 end_ARG ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG < square-root start_ARG 0.5 end_ARG ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0.5 ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ,

and

‚Ñô‚Å°(39‚Å¢2g‚Å¢h0<39‚Å¢2g‚Å¢49)=‚Ñô‚Å°(h0<49)=‚Ñô‚Å°(h0<49)=49‚âà0.4444.‚Ñô392ùëîsubscript‚Ñé0392ùëî49‚Ñôsubscript‚Ñé049‚Ñôsubscript‚Ñé049490.4444\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\sqrt{h_{0}}<39\sqrt{\frac{% 2}{g}}\sqrt{\frac{4}{9}}\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{h_{0}}<% \sqrt{\frac{4}{9}}\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h_{0}<\frac{4}{9}% \right)=\frac{4}{9}\approx 0.4444.blackboard_P ( 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG < 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG end_ARG ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG < square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG end_ARG ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ‚âà 0.4444 .

The reason for choosing 4949\frac{4}{9}divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG is that, in the solution of parts (i) and (ii), we have seen that the expectation of the total time that elapses before the ball stops moving is equal to the total time that elapses before a ball dropped from a height of 4949\frac{4}{9}divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG stops moving, that is, ùîº‚Å°(39‚Å¢2g‚Å¢h0)=39‚Å¢2g‚Å¢49ùîº392ùëîsubscript‚Ñé0392ùëî49\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\sqrt{h_{0}}\right)=39\sqrt% {\frac{2}{g}}\sqrt{\frac{4}{9}}blackboard_E ( 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) = 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG end_ARG. This also provides an example for the fact that given two random variables Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ and Œ∂ùúÅ\zetaitalic_Œ∂, it can happen that their expected values are equal, i.e., ùîº‚Å°(Œ∑)=ùîº‚Å°(Œ∂)ùîºùúÇùîºùúÅ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\eta)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\zeta)blackboard_E ( italic_Œ∑ ) = blackboard_E ( italic_Œ∂ ), but ‚Ñô‚Å°(Œ∑<Œ∂)‚â†12‚ÑôùúÇùúÅ12\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\eta<\zeta)\neq\frac{1}{2}blackboard_P ( italic_Œ∑ < italic_Œ∂ ) ‚â† divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG.

(iv). The range of the random variable Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ is {0,1,2,‚Ä¶}012‚Ä¶\{0,1,2,\ldots\}{ 0 , 1 , 2 , ‚Ä¶ }, but we will check that Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ takes every positive even number with probability 00, and it will also turn out that there exists a natural number n0subscriptùëõ0n_{0}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that the probability that Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ takes a value greater than n0subscriptùëõ0n_{0}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is 00.

and, since h0subscript‚Ñé0h_{0}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is has an absolutely continuous distribution,

One can also see that

‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=3)=‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=1)0.952>‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=1).‚Ñôùúâ3‚Ñôùúâ1superscript0.952‚Ñôùúâ1\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=3)=\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=1)}{0.95^% {2}}>\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=1).blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 3 ) = divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG > blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 1 ) .

In what follows, let k‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶}ùëò12‚Ä¶k\in\{1,2,\ldots\}italic_k ‚àà { 1 , 2 , ‚Ä¶ }. Since h0subscript‚Ñé0h_{0}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is absolutely continuous, we obtain that ‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=2‚Å¢k)=0‚Ñôùúâ2ùëò0\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k)=0blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 2 italic_k ) = 0, and

‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=2‚Å¢k+1)‚Ñôùúâ2ùëò1\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k+1)blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 2 italic_k + 1 ) =‚Ñô‚Å°({h0>0.1}‚à©‚ãÇj=1k{vj22‚Å¢g>0.1}‚à©{vk+122‚Å¢g<0.1})absent‚Ñôsubscript‚Ñé00.1superscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë£ùëó22ùëî0.1superscriptsubscriptùë£ùëò122ùëî0.1\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\{h_{0}>0.1\}\cap\bigcap_{j=1}^{k% }\Big{\{}\frac{v_{j}^{2}}{2g}>0.1\Big{\}}\cap\Big{\{}\frac{v_{k+1}^{2}}{2g}<0.% 1\Big{\}}\right)= blackboard_P ( { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.1 } ‚à© ‚ãÇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT { divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG > 0.1 } ‚à© { divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG < 0.1 } )

Using that the inequality 0.10.952‚Å¢(k+1)<10.1superscript0.952ùëò11\frac{0.1}{0.95^{2(k+1)}}<1divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 ( italic_k + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG < 1 holds if and only if

ln‚Å°(0.1)<2‚Å¢(k+1)‚Å¢ln‚Å°(0.95)‚ü∫ln‚Å°(0.1)2‚Å¢ln‚Å°(0.95)‚àí1>k‚ü∫k‚©Ω21,formulae-sequence0.12ùëò10.95‚ü∫formulae-sequence0.120.951ùëò‚ü∫ùëò21\displaystyle\ln(0.1)<2(k+1)\ln(0.95)\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad\frac{\ln(0.% 1)}{2\ln(0.95)}-1>k\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad k\leqslant 21,roman_ln ( 0.1 ) < 2 ( italic_k + 1 ) roman_ln ( 0.95 ) ‚ü∫ divide start_ARG roman_ln ( 0.1 ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 roman_ln ( 0.95 ) end_ARG - 1 > italic_k ‚ü∫ italic_k ‚©Ω 21 ,
