we get that for each k‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶}ùëò12‚Ä¶k\in\{1,2,\ldots\}italic_k ‚àà { 1 , 2 , ‚Ä¶ },

‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=2‚Å¢k+1)={0.1‚Å¢(10.952‚àí1)‚Å¢0.95‚àí2‚Å¢kif¬†k‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶,21},1‚àí0.10.952‚Å¢kif¬†k=22,0if¬†k‚©æ23.‚Ñôùúâ2ùëò1cases0.11superscript0.9521superscript0.952ùëòif¬†k‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶,21},10.1superscript0.952ùëòif¬†k=22,0if¬†k‚©æ23.\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k+1)=\begin{cases}0.1\left(\frac{1% }{0.95^{2}}-1\right)0.95^{-2k}&\text{if \ $k\in\{1,2,\ldots,21\}$,}\\ 1-\frac{0.1}{0.95^{2k}}&\text{if \ $k=22$,}\\ 0&\text{if \ $k\geqslant 23$.}\end{cases}blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 2 italic_k + 1 ) = { start_ROW start_CELL 0.1 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 ) 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL if italic_k ‚àà { 1 , 2 , ‚Ä¶ , 21 } , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 - divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL if italic_k = 22 , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_k ‚©æ 23 . end_CELL end_ROW

All in all, the distribution of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ takes the form

‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=0)=0.1,‚Ñôùúâ00.1\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=0)=0.1,blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 0 ) = 0.1 ,
‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=2‚Å¢k+1)=0.1‚Å¢(10.952‚àí1)‚Å¢0.95‚àí2‚Å¢k=0.95‚àí2‚Å¢k‚Å¢‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=1),k‚àà{0,1,2,‚Ä¶,21},formulae-sequence‚Ñôùúâ2ùëò10.11superscript0.9521superscript0.952ùëòsuperscript0.952ùëò‚Ñôùúâ1ùëò012‚Ä¶21\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k+1)=0.1\left(\frac{1}{0.95^{2}}-1% \right)0.95^{-2k}=0.95^{-2k}\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=1),\qquad k\in\{0,1,% 2,\ldots,21\},blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 2 italic_k + 1 ) = 0.1 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 ) 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 1 ) , italic_k ‚àà { 0 , 1 , 2 , ‚Ä¶ , 21 } ,
‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=45)=1‚àí0.10.9544‚âà0.04465.‚Ñôùúâ4510.1superscript0.95440.04465\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=45)=1-\frac{0.1}{0.95^{44}}\approx 0% .04465.blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 45 ) = 1 - divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 44 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚âà 0.04465 .

One can check that the given values are indeed a probability distribution, since the given values are trivially nonnegative and

0.1+‚àëk=0210.1‚Å¢(10.952‚àí1)‚Å¢0.95‚àí2‚Å¢k+1‚àí0.10.95440.1superscriptsubscriptùëò0210.11superscript0.9521superscript0.952ùëò10.1superscript0.9544\displaystyle 0.1+\sum_{k=0}^{21}0.1\left(\frac{1}{0.95^{2}}-1\right)0.95^{-2k% }+1-\frac{0.1}{0.95^{44}}0.1 + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 21 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.1 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 ) 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 - divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 44 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG
=0.1+0.1‚Å¢(10.952‚àí1)‚ãÖ(0.95‚àí2)22‚àí10.95‚àí2‚àí1+1‚àí0.10.9544=1.absent0.1‚ãÖ0.11superscript0.9521superscriptsuperscript0.952221superscript0.952110.1superscript0.95441\displaystyle\qquad=0.1+0.1\left(\frac{1}{0.95^{2}}-1\right)\cdot\frac{(0.95^{% -2})^{22}-1}{0.95^{-2}-1}+1-\frac{0.1}{0.95^{44}}=1.= 0.1 + 0.1 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 ) ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG ( 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 22 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG + 1 - divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 44 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = 1 .

This implies that the expectation of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ is

ùîº‚Å°(Œæ)ùîºùúâ\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) =0‚ãÖ0.1+‚àëk=021(2‚Å¢k+1)‚ãÖ0.1‚Å¢(10.952‚àí1)‚Å¢0.95‚àí2‚Å¢k+45‚Å¢(1‚àí0.10.9544)absent‚ãÖ00.1superscriptsubscriptùëò021‚ãÖ2ùëò10.11superscript0.9521superscript0.952ùëò4510.1superscript0.9544\displaystyle=0\cdot 0.1+\sum_{k=0}^{21}(2k+1)\cdot 0.1\left(\frac{1}{0.95^{2}% }-1\right)0.95^{-2k}+45\left(1-\frac{0.1}{0.95^{44}}\right)= 0 ‚ãÖ 0.1 + ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 21 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 italic_k + 1 ) ‚ãÖ 0.1 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 ) 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 45 ( 1 - divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 44 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG )
=44.9‚àí4.40.9544+0.2‚Å¢1‚àí0.9520.952‚Å¢‚àëk=121k‚ãÖ0.95‚àí2‚Å¢k‚âà27.35.absent44.94.4superscript0.95440.21superscript0.952superscript0.952superscriptsubscriptùëò121‚ãÖùëòsuperscript0.952ùëò27.35\displaystyle=44.9-\frac{4.4}{0.95^{44}}+0.2\frac{1-0.95^{2}}{0.95^{2}}\sum_{k% =1}^{21}k\cdot 0.95^{-2k}\approx 27.35.= 44.9 - divide start_ARG 4.4 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 44 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + 0.2 divide start_ARG 1 - 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 21 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k ‚ãÖ 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚âà 27.35 .

Note that the function {0,1,‚Ä¶,21}‚àãk‚Ü¶‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=2‚Å¢k+1)contains01‚Ä¶21ùëòmaps-to‚Ñôùúâ2ùëò1\{0,1,\ldots,21\}\ni k\mapsto\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k+1){ 0 , 1 , ‚Ä¶ , 21 } ‚àã italic_k ‚Ü¶ blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 2 italic_k + 1 ) is strictly increasing, however, the function {0,1,‚Ä¶,22}‚àãk‚Ü¶‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=2‚Å¢k+1)contains01‚Ä¶22ùëòmaps-to‚Ñôùúâ2ùëò1\{0,1,\ldots,22\}\ni k\mapsto\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k+1){ 0 , 1 , ‚Ä¶ , 22 } ‚àã italic_k ‚Ü¶ blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 2 italic_k + 1 ) is not strictly increasing, since ‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=43)‚âà0.09315‚Ñôùúâ430.09315\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=43)\approx 0.09315blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 43 ) ‚âà 0.09315, which is greater than ‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=45)‚âà0.04465‚Ñôùúâ450.04465\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=45)\approx 0.04465blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 45 ) ‚âà 0.04465. Remark also that the (unique) maximum of the probabilities ‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=0)‚Ñôùúâ0\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=0)blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 0 ) and ‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=2‚Å¢k+1)‚Ñôùúâ2ùëò1\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k+1)blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 2 italic_k + 1 ), k‚àà{0,1,‚Ä¶,22}ùëò01‚Ä¶22k\in\{0,1,\ldots,22\}italic_k ‚àà { 0 , 1 , ‚Ä¶ , 22 } is equal to ‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=0)=0.1‚Ñôùúâ00.1\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=0)=0.1blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = 0 ) = 0.1, yielding that the mode of the distribution of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ is 00. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

The next exercise is a randomized version of Exercise 2, Round I, Category I at the S√°ndor Mikola Physics Competition (2023) (see [4]) in the sense that we consider the so-called collision number appearing in the exercise as a random variable. We also point out that the deterministic counterparts of the questions that we consider in our next exercise are not included in the exercise at the S√°ndor Mikola Physics Competition.

2.4 Exercise.

According to the International Tennis Federation, a tennis ball is considered standard if, when dropped on concrete from a height of 254 cm, the rebound height falls between 135 cm and 147 cm. By collision number, by definition, we mean the ratio of the rebound and landing speeds when a tennis ball is dropped on concrete from a height of 254 cm. The companies A and B produce tennis balls. In case of Company A, the collision number is a random variable with uniform distribution on the interval [0.7,0.8]0.70.8[0.7,0.8][ 0.7 , 0.8 ], and in case of Company B, it an absolutely continuous random variable with a density function

fB‚Å¢(x)={200‚Å¢x‚àí140if¬†x‚àà[0.7,0.8],0otherwise.subscriptùëìùêµùë•cases200ùë•140if¬†x‚àà[0.7,0.8],0otherwise.f_{B}(x)=\begin{cases}200x-140&\text{if $x\in[0.7,0.8]$,}\\ 0&\text{otherwise.}\end{cases}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = { start_ROW start_CELL 200 italic_x - 140 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ‚àà [ 0.7 , 0.8 ] , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL otherwise. end_CELL end_ROW
  1. (i)

    We drop a tennis ball produced by Company A on concrete from a height of 254 cm. How high is the bounce back expected to be? Answer the same question for a tennis ball produced by Company B.

  2. (ii)

    What is the probability that a tennis ball produced by Company A is standard? Answer the same question for a tennis ball produced by Company B.

  3. (iii)

    Company A and B send us 40 and 60 tennis balls, respectively, as a promotional gift. We mix the 100 tennis balls, we randomly choose one of them and then, by dropping it on concrete from a height of 254 cm, we classify it standard. What is the probability that the tennis ball was produced by company A?

Solution. If we drop a ball from a height of hlsubscript‚Ñéùëôh_{l}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it has velocity vl=2‚Å¢g‚Å¢hlsubscriptùë£ùëô2ùëîsubscript‚Ñéùëôv_{l}=\sqrt{2gh_{l}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG when it hits the ground. Furthermore, if its rebounce velocity is vfsubscriptùë£ùëìv_{f}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then, for the rebounce height denoted by hfsubscript‚Ñéùëìh_{f}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it holds that vf=2‚Å¢g‚Å¢hfsubscriptùë£ùëì2ùëîsubscript‚Ñéùëìv_{f}=\sqrt{2gh_{f}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG.

With these notations, the collision number takes the form

vfvl=2‚Å¢g‚Å¢hf2‚Å¢g‚ãÖ2.54=hf2.54.subscriptùë£ùëìsubscriptùë£ùëô2ùëîsubscript‚Ñéùëì‚ãÖ2ùëî2.54subscript‚Ñéùëì2.54\frac{v_{f}}{v_{l}}=\frac{\sqrt{2gh_{f}}}{\sqrt{2g\cdot 2.54}}=\sqrt{\frac{h_{% f}}{2.54}}.divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g ‚ãÖ 2.54 end_ARG end_ARG = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2.54 end_ARG end_ARG .

In what follows, we denote the collision number by Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ, i.e., Œæ:=vfvlassignùúâsubscriptùë£ùëìsubscriptùë£ùëô\xi:=\frac{v_{f}}{v_{l}}italic_Œæ := divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Then the rebounce height is hf=2.54‚ãÖŒæ2subscript‚Ñéùëì‚ãÖ2.54superscriptùúâ2h_{f}=2.54\cdot\xi^{2}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2.54 ‚ãÖ italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

(i). In case of Company A, Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ is uniformly distributed on the interval [0.7,0.8]0.70.8[0.7,0.8][ 0.7 , 0.8 ], and hence we have that

ùîº‚Å°(hf)=2.54‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(Œæ2)=2.54‚Å¢‚à´0.70.8x2‚Å¢10.1‚Å¢dx=25.43‚Å¢(0.83‚àí0.73)‚âà1.431,ùîºsubscript‚Ñéùëì2.54ùîºsuperscriptùúâ22.54superscriptsubscript0.70.8superscriptùë•210.1differential-dùë•25.43superscript0.83superscript0.731.431\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(h_{f})=2.54\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(% \xi^{2})=2.54\int_{0.7}^{0.8}x^{2}\frac{1}{0.1}\,\mathrm{d}x=\frac{25.4}{3}(0.% 8^{3}-0.7^{3})\approx 1.431,blackboard_E ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 2.54 blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 2.54 ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0.7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG roman_d italic_x = divide start_ARG 25.4 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( 0.8 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 0.7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ‚âà 1.431 ,

i.e., a tennis ball produced by Company A rebounds to the expected height of approximately 143.1 cm dropped from a height of 254 cm.

In case of Company B, Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ is an absolutely continuous random variable with a density function fBsubscriptùëìùêµf_{B}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then we get that

ùîº‚Å°(hf)ùîºsubscript‚Ñéùëì\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(h_{f})blackboard_E ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =2.54‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(Œæ2)=2.54‚Å¢‚à´0.70.8x2‚Å¢(200‚Å¢x‚àí140)‚Å¢dx=2.54‚Å¢‚à´0.70.8(200‚Å¢x3‚àí140‚Å¢x2)‚Å¢dxabsent2.54ùîºsuperscriptùúâ22.54superscriptsubscript0.70.8superscriptùë•2200ùë•140differential-dùë•2.54superscriptsubscript0.70.8200superscriptùë•3140superscriptùë•2differential-dùë•\displaystyle=2.54\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi^{2})=2.54\int_{0.7}^{0.8}x^{2}% (200x-140)\,\mathrm{d}x=2.54\int_{0.7}^{0.8}(200x^{3}-140x^{2})\,\mathrm{d}x= 2.54 blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 2.54 ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0.7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 200 italic_x - 140 ) roman_d italic_x = 2.54 ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0.7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 200 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 140 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_x
=2.54‚Å¢(50‚Å¢(0.84‚àí0.74)‚àí1403‚Å¢(0.83‚àí0.73))‚âà1.494,absent2.5450superscript0.84superscript0.741403superscript0.83superscript0.731.494\displaystyle=2.54\Big{(}50(0.8^{4}-0.7^{4})-\frac{140}{3}(0.8^{3}-0.7^{3})% \Big{)}\approx 1.494,= 2.54 ( 50 ( 0.8 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 0.7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - divide start_ARG 140 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( 0.8 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 0.7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ‚âà 1.494 ,

i.e., a tennis ball produced by Company B rebounds to the expected height of approximately 1.494 cm dropped from a height of 254 cm.

(ii). Using that

{a tennis ball is standard}={hf‚àà(1.35,1.47)},a tennis ball is standardsubscript‚Ñéùëì1.351.47\Big{\{}\text{a tennis ball is standard}\Big{\}}=\{h_{f}\in(1.35,1.47)\},{ a tennis ball is standard } = { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà ( 1.35 , 1.47 ) } ,

we get that, in case of Company A, the probability that a tennis ball is standard is

‚Ñô‚Å°(hf‚àà(1.35,1.47))‚Ñôsubscript‚Ñéùëì1.351.47\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h_{f}\in(1.35,1.47))blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà ( 1.35 , 1.47 ) ) =‚Ñô‚Å°(1.35<2.54‚ãÖŒæ2<1.47)=‚Ñô‚Å°(135254<Œæ<147254)absent‚Ñô1.35‚ãÖ2.54superscriptùúâ21.47‚Ñô135254ùúâ147254\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(1.35<2.54\cdot\xi^{2}<1.47)=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}<\xi<\sqrt{\frac{147}{25% 4}}\Big{)}= blackboard_P ( 1.35 < 2.54 ‚ãÖ italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 1.47 ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG < italic_Œæ < square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG )
=147254‚àí1352540.8‚àí0.7‚âà0.3171,absent1472541352540.80.70.3171\displaystyle=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}}{0.8-0.7}% \approx 0.3171,= divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 0.8 - 0.7 end_ARG ‚âà 0.3171 ,

and, in case of Company B, is

‚Ñô‚Å°(hf‚àà(1.35,1.47))‚Ñôsubscript‚Ñéùëì1.351.47\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h_{f}\in(1.35,1.47))blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà ( 1.35 , 1.47 ) ) =‚Ñô‚Å°(1.35<2.54‚ãÖŒæ2<1.47)=‚Ñô‚Å°(135254<Œæ<147254)absent‚Ñô1.35‚ãÖ2.54superscriptùúâ21.47‚Ñô135254ùúâ147254\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(1.35<2.54\cdot\xi^{2}<1.47)=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}<\xi<\sqrt{\frac{147}{25% 4}}\Big{)}= blackboard_P ( 1.35 < 2.54 ‚ãÖ italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 1.47 ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG < italic_Œæ < square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG )
=‚à´135254147254(200‚Å¢x‚àí140)‚Å¢dx=1200254‚àí140‚Å¢(147254‚àí135254)‚âà0.2847.absentsuperscriptsubscript135254147254200ùë•140differential-dùë•12002541401472541352540.2847\displaystyle=\int_{\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}}^{\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}}(200x-140)% \,\mathrm{d}x=\frac{1200}{254}-140\left(\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135% }{254}}\right)\approx 0.2847.= ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 200 italic_x - 140 ) roman_d italic_x = divide start_ARG 1200 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG - 140 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG ) ‚âà 0.2847 .

(iii). Let us introduce the following events

GA:={the chosen tennis ball was produced by Company A},assignsubscriptùê∫ùê¥the chosen tennis ball was produced by Company A\displaystyle G_{A}:=\Big{\{}\text{the chosen tennis ball was produced by % Company A}\Big{\}},italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { the chosen tennis ball was produced by Company A } ,
GB:={the chosen tennis ball was produced by Company B},assignsubscriptùê∫ùêµthe chosen tennis ball was produced by Company B\displaystyle G_{B}:=\Big{\{}\text{the chosen tennis ball was produced by % Company B}\Big{\}},italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { the chosen tennis ball was produced by Company B } ,
S:={the chosen tennis ball is standard}.assignùëÜthe chosen tennis ball is standard\displaystyle S:=\Big{\{}\text{the chosen tennis ball is standard}\Big{\}}.italic_S := { the chosen tennis ball is standard } .

We need to calculate the conditional probability ‚Ñô‚Å°(GA|S)‚Ñôconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùê¥ùëÜ\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(G_{A}\,|\,S)blackboard_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S ). Since GAsubscriptùê∫ùê¥G_{A}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and GBsubscriptùê∫ùêµG_{B}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are disjoint events with positive probability and their union is the whole sample space, one can apply Bayes‚Äô theorem (see (A.1)) and we get that

‚Ñô‚Å°(GA|S)‚Ñôconditionalsubscriptùê∫ùê¥ùëÜ\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(G_{A}\,|\,S)blackboard_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S ) =‚Ñô‚Å°(S|GA)‚Å¢‚Ñô‚Å°(GA)‚Ñô‚Å°(S|GA)‚Å¢‚Ñô‚Å°(GA)+‚Ñô‚Å°(S|GB)‚Å¢‚Ñô‚Å°(GB)absent‚ÑôconditionalùëÜsubscriptùê∫ùê¥‚Ñôsubscriptùê∫ùê¥‚ÑôconditionalùëÜsubscriptùê∫ùê¥‚Ñôsubscriptùê∫ùê¥‚ÑôconditionalùëÜsubscriptùê∫ùêµ‚Ñôsubscriptùê∫ùêµ\displaystyle=\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S\,|\,G_{A})\operatorname{% \mathbb{P}}(G_{A})}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S\,|\,G_{A})\operatorname{% \mathbb{P}}(G_{A})+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S\,|\,G_{B})\operatorname{\mathbb% {P}}(G_{B})}= divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_S | italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) blackboard_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_S | italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) blackboard_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + blackboard_P ( italic_S | italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) blackboard_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG
=147254‚àí1352540.8‚àí0.7‚ãÖ0.4147254‚àí1352540.8‚àí0.7‚ãÖ0.4+(1200254‚àí140‚Å¢(147254‚àí135254))‚ãÖ0.6absent‚ãÖ1472541352540.80.70.4‚ãÖ1472541352540.80.70.4‚ãÖ12002541401472541352540.6\displaystyle=\frac{\frac{\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}}{0.8-0% .7}\cdot 0.4}{\frac{\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}}{0.8-0.7}% \cdot 0.4+\left(\frac{1200}{254}-140\left(\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{1% 35}{254}}\right)\right)\cdot 0.6}= divide start_ARG divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 0.8 - 0.7 end_ARG ‚ãÖ 0.4 end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 0.8 - 0.7 end_ARG ‚ãÖ 0.4 + ( divide start_ARG 1200 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG - 140 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG ) ) ‚ãÖ 0.6 end_ARG
=4‚Å¢(147254‚àí135254)720254‚àí80‚Å¢(147254‚àí135254)‚âà0.4261.absent4147254135254720254801472541352540.4261\displaystyle=\frac{4\left(\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}\right% )}{\frac{720}{254}-80\left(\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}\right% )}\approx 0.4261.= divide start_ARG 4 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG 720 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG - 80 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG ) end_ARG ‚âà 0.4261 .

‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

Part (i) of the next Exercise 2.5 is a randomized version of Exercise 1, Round II, Category III at the S√°ndor Mikola Physics Competition (2023) (see [4]) in the sense that the precise theoretical value of the gravity of Earth is considered to be a random value. Note that this kind of normalization is different from the ones in Exercises 2.1-2.3 in the sense that the uncertainty in a system‚Äôs parameter is studied in Exercise 2.5 instead of the uncertainty in some of the inputs of a dynamical system.

2.5 Exercise.

Let gùëîgitalic_g denote the (theoretical) value of the gravity of Earth and let Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ be a uniformly distributed random variable on the interval [‚àí1,1]11[-1,1][ - 1 , 1 ]. What is the expectation of the relative error that we make if the gravity of Earth is taken to be (g+Œæ)ùëîùúâ(g+\xi)( italic_g + italic_Œæ ) instead of the theoretical value gùëîgitalic_g and

  • (i)

    we calculate the distance traveled by a free-falling body over a given period of time?

  • (ii)

    we calculate the time needed by a free-falling body to travel a given distance?

Solution. It is known that a free-falling body travels a distance g2‚Å¢t2ùëî2superscriptùë°2\frac{g}{2}t^{2}divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over a given period of time tùë°titalic_t, and it needs a time 2‚Å¢hg2‚Ñéùëî\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG to travel a given distance h‚Ñéhitalic_h.

(i). The relative error of the distances over a given time period tùë°titalic_t (with respect to the distance calculated by the theoretical value of gùëîgitalic_g) is

g+Œæ2‚Å¢t2‚àíg2‚Å¢t2g2‚Å¢t2=Œæg.ùëîùúâ2superscriptùë°2ùëî2superscriptùë°2ùëî2superscriptùë°2ùúâùëî\frac{\frac{g+\xi}{2}t^{2}-\frac{g}{2}t^{2}}{\frac{g}{2}t^{2}}=\frac{\xi}{g}.divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_g + italic_Œæ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_Œæ end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG .

Consequently, the expected value of Œægùúâùëî\frac{\xi}{g}divide start_ARG italic_Œæ end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG is

ùîº‚Å°(Œæg)=1g‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(Œæ)=1g‚ãÖ‚àí1+12=0,ùîºùúâùëî1ùëîùîºùúâ‚ãÖ1ùëî1120\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{\xi}{g}\right)=\frac{1}{g}\operatorname{% \mathbb{E}}(\xi)=\frac{1}{g}\cdot\frac{-1+1}{2}=0,blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG italic_Œæ end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG - 1 + 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = 0 ,

that is, the expected value of the relative error in question is 00.

(ii). The relative error of the times needed for travelling a given distance h‚Ñéhitalic_h (with respect to the time calculated by the theoretical value of gùëîgitalic_g) is

2‚Å¢hg+Œæ‚àí2‚Å¢hg2‚Å¢hg=gg+Œæ‚àí1.2‚Ñéùëîùúâ2‚Ñéùëî2‚Ñéùëîùëîùëîùúâ1\displaystyle\frac{\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g+\xi}}-\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}}{\sqrt{\frac{2h% }{g}}}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{g+\xi}}-1.divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g + italic_Œæ end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_g + italic_Œæ end_ARG end_ARG - 1 .

Consequently, we get that

ùîº‚Å°(gg+Œæ‚àí1)=g‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(1g+Œæ)‚àí1=g‚Å¢‚à´‚àí111g+x‚ãÖ12‚Å¢dx‚àí1ùîºùëîùëîùúâ1ùëîùîº1ùëîùúâ1ùëîsuperscriptsubscript11‚ãÖ1ùëîùë•12differential-dùë•1\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{g}{g+\xi}}-1\right)=% \sqrt{g}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{g+\xi}}\right)-1=\sqrt{g% }\int_{-1}^{1}\frac{1}{\sqrt{g+x}}\cdot\frac{1}{2}\,\mathrm{d}x-1blackboard_E ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_g + italic_Œæ end_ARG end_ARG - 1 ) = square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g + italic_Œæ end_ARG end_ARG ) - 1 = square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g + italic_x end_ARG end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_d italic_x - 1
=g‚Å¢(g+1‚àíg‚àí1)‚àí1=2‚Å¢gg+1+g‚àí1‚àí1=2‚Å¢g‚àíg+1‚àíg‚àí1g+1+g‚àí1.absentùëîùëî1ùëî112ùëîùëî1ùëî112ùëîùëî1ùëî1ùëî1ùëî1\displaystyle=\sqrt{g}(\sqrt{g+1}-\sqrt{g-1})-1=\frac{2\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{g+1}+% \sqrt{g-1}}-1=\frac{2\sqrt{g}-\sqrt{g+1}-\sqrt{g-1}}{\sqrt{g+1}+\sqrt{g-1}}.= square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( square-root start_ARG italic_g + 1 end_ARG - square-root start_ARG italic_g - 1 end_ARG ) - 1 = divide start_ARG 2 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g + 1 end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_g - 1 end_ARG end_ARG - 1 = divide start_ARG 2 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG - square-root start_ARG italic_g + 1 end_ARG - square-root start_ARG italic_g - 1 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g + 1 end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_g - 1 end_ARG end_ARG .

This expected value is positive, since the function [0,‚àû)‚àãx‚Ü¶xcontains0ùë•maps-toùë•[0,\infty)\ni x\mapsto\sqrt{x}[ 0 , ‚àû ) ‚àã italic_x ‚Ü¶ square-root start_ARG italic_x end_ARG is strictly concave, and hence

g+1+g‚àí12>12‚Å¢(g+1)+12‚Å¢(g‚àí1)=g.ùëî1ùëî1212ùëî112ùëî1ùëî\frac{\sqrt{g+1}+\sqrt{g-1}}{2}>\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}(g+1)+\frac{1}{2}(g-1)}=\sqrt% {g}.divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g + 1 end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_g - 1 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG > square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_g + 1 ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_g - 1 ) end_ARG = square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG .

In our present paper, the theoretical value of gùëîgitalic_g is considered to be 9.819.819.819.81, and hence the expected value of the relative error in question is approximately 0.0013050.0013050.0013050.001305.

Finally, we call the attention to the fact that, in part (i), the expected value of the relative error does not depend on the theoretical value of gùëîgitalic_g, while in part (ii), it does. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

3 A stochastic approach in statics

In this section, we demonstrate our method for incorporating a stochastic point of view into physics exercises of mathematics education by presenting exercises for statics. In them, we randomize the geometry of the static problem, for example, the shape of a plate or the position of some of the pinning points of a plate. To avoid technicalities, we choose uniform distributions as the distributions of the random inputs. Altogether, we present three exercises in this section.

3.1 Exercise.

A square piece of homogeneous sheet metal of side length 1 m and mass mùëömitalic_m kg is bent in the following way: on one side, at a point chosen at a distance of 1414\frac{1}{4}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG from one of the vertices, a perpendicular is set on that side, and we bend the metal sheet along this perpendicular in a way that the angle between the two pieces is uniformly distributed on the interval (0,œÄ2)0ùúã2(0,\frac{\pi}{2})( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ). We place the bent plate with its smaller part on a horizontal surface, and then release it.

  • (i)

    What is the probability that it does not fall over?

  • (ii)

    What is the probability that the perpendicular projection of the center of gravity of the larger part of the bent plate falls on the smaller part of the bent plate given that the bent plate does not fall over?

Solution. Figure 6 shows a planar section of the bent plate corresponding to a plane, which is perpendicular to the bending line at a point (denoted by TùëáTitalic_T).

Let Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± denote the angle between the two pieces. Then Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± is a random variable with uniform distribution on the interval (0,œÄ2)0ùúã2(0,\frac{\pi}{2})( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ). Let S1subscriptùëÜ1S_{1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and S2subscriptùëÜ2S_{2}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the centers of gravity of the larger and smaller parts of the plate, respectively, and let RùëÖRitalic_R be the endpoint different from TùëáTitalic_T of the planar section of the smaller part. Let

ùë≠1:=[0‚àím‚Å¢g‚Å¢34]andùë≠2:=[0‚àím‚Å¢g‚Å¢14].formulae-sequenceassignsubscriptùë≠1matrix0ùëöùëî34andassignsubscriptùë≠2matrix0ùëöùëî14{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}:=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ -mg\frac{3}{4}\\ \end{bmatrix}\qquad\text{and}\qquad{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}:=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ -mg\frac{1}{4}\\ \end{bmatrix}.bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] and bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

(i). Then {the bent plate does not fall over}=A‚à™Bthe bent plate does not fall overùê¥ùêµ\{\text{the bent plate does not fall over}\}=A\cup B{ the bent plate does not fall over } = italic_A ‚à™ italic_B, where the events Aùê¥Aitalic_A and BùêµBitalic_B are defined by

A:={the perpendicular projection of¬†S1¬†falls on the section¬†T‚Å¢R},assignùê¥the perpendicular projection of¬†S1¬†falls on the section¬†T‚Å¢RA:=\Big{\{}\text{the perpendicular projection of $S_{1}$ falls on the section % $TR$}\Big{\}},italic_A := { the perpendicular projection of italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT falls on the section italic_T italic_R } ,

and

B:=assignùêµabsent\displaystyle B:=italic_B := {the perpendicular projection of¬†S1¬†does not fall on the section¬†T‚Å¢R}the perpendicular projection of¬†S1¬†does not fall on the section¬†T‚Å¢R\displaystyle\Big{\{}\text{the perpendicular projection of $S_{1}$ does not % fall on the section $TR$}\Big{\}}{ the perpendicular projection of italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not fall on the section italic_T italic_R }
‚à©{the magnitude of the moment of force of¬†ùë≠2¬†with respect to¬†R¬†is greater than\displaystyle\cap\Big{\{}\text{the magnitude of the moment of force of ${% \boldsymbol{F}}_{2}$ with respect to $R$ is greater than }‚à© { the magnitude of the moment of force of bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to italic_R is greater than
or equal to the magnitude of the moment of force of¬†ùë≠1¬†with respect to¬†R}.\displaystyle\phantom{\cap\Big{\{}\Big{\{}}\text{or equal to the magnitude of % the moment of force of ${\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}$ with respect to $R$}\Big{\}}.or equal to the magnitude of the moment of force of bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to italic_R } .

Then the events Aùê¥Aitalic_A and BùêµBitalic_B are disjoint, and using that the distance between the perpendicular projection of S1subscriptùëÜ1S_{1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the point TùëáTitalic_T is 38‚Å¢cos‚Å°(Œ±)38ùõº\frac{3}{8}\cos(\alpha)divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) and the length of the section T‚Å¢RùëáùëÖTRitalic_T italic_R is 1414\frac{1}{4}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG, we get that

A={38‚Å¢cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚©Ω14},ùê¥38ùõº14\displaystyle A=\left\{\frac{3}{8}\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{1}{4}\right\},italic_A = { divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) ‚©Ω divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG } ,
B={38‚Å¢cos‚Å°(Œ±)>14}‚à©{m‚Å¢g‚Å¢14‚ãÖ18‚©æm‚Å¢g‚Å¢34‚ãÖ(38‚Å¢cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚àí14)}.ùêµ38ùõº14‚ãÖùëöùëî1418‚ãÖùëöùëî3438ùõº14\displaystyle B=\left\{\frac{3}{8}\cos(\alpha)>\frac{1}{4}\right\}\cap\left\{% mg\frac{1}{4}\cdot\frac{1}{8}\geqslant mg\frac{3}{4}\cdot\left(\frac{3}{8}\cos% (\alpha)-\frac{1}{4}\right)\right\}.italic_B = { divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) > divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG } ‚à© { italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ‚©æ italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ‚ãÖ ( divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ) } .

Consequently, we have that A={cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚©Ω23}ùê¥ùõº23A=\Big{\{}\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{2}{3}\Big{\}}italic_A = { roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) ‚©Ω divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } and

Bùêµ\displaystyle Bitalic_B ={cos‚Å°(Œ±)>23}‚à©{124‚©æ38‚Å¢cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚àí14}={cos‚Å°(Œ±)>23}‚à©{cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚©Ω79}absentùõº2312438ùõº14ùõº23ùõº79\displaystyle=\left\{\cos(\alpha)>\frac{2}{3}\right\}\cap\left\{\frac{1}{24}% \geqslant\frac{3}{8}\cos(\alpha)-\frac{1}{4}\right\}=\left\{\cos(\alpha)>\frac% {2}{3}\right\}\cap\left\{\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{7}{9}\right\}= { roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) > divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } ‚à© { divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 24 end_ARG ‚©æ divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG } = { roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) > divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } ‚à© { roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) ‚©Ω divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG }
={23<cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚©Ω79}.absent23ùõº79\displaystyle=\left\{\frac{2}{3}<\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{7}{9}\right\}.= { divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG < roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) ‚©Ω divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG } .

Hence {the bent plate does not fall over}={cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚©Ω79}the bent plate does not fall overùõº79\{\text{the bent plate does not fall over}\}=\{\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{7}{9}\}{ the bent plate does not fall over } = { roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) ‚©Ω divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG }. Here the inequality cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚©Ω79ùõº79\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{7}{9}roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) ‚©Ω divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG, Œ±‚àà(0,œÄ2)ùõº0ùúã2\alpha\in(0,\frac{\pi}{2})italic_Œ± ‚àà ( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) holds if and only if Œ±‚àà[Œ±0,œÄ2)ùõºsubscriptùõº0ùúã2\alpha\in[\alpha_{0},\frac{\pi}{2})italic_Œ± ‚àà [ italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ), where Œ±0‚àà(0,œÄ2)subscriptùõº00ùúã2\alpha_{0}\in(0,\frac{\pi}{2})italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà ( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) is the unique value for which cos‚Å°(Œ±0)=79subscriptùõº079\cos(\alpha_{0})=\frac{7}{9}roman_cos ( italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG, i.e., Œ±0=arccos‚Å°(79)‚âà0.6797subscriptùõº0790.6797\alpha_{0}=\arccos\left(\frac{7}{9}\right)\approx 0.6797italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) ‚âà 0.6797. Consequently, we have

{the bent plate does not fall over}=A‚à™B={Œ±0‚©ΩŒ±<œÄ2},the bent plate does not fall overùê¥ùêµsubscriptùõº0ùõºùúã2\{\text{the bent plate does not fall over}\}=A\cup B=\left\{\alpha_{0}% \leqslant\alpha<\frac{\pi}{2}\right\},{ the bent plate does not fall over } = italic_A ‚à™ italic_B = { italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚©Ω italic_Œ± < divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG } ,

and note that the angle Œ±0subscriptùõº0\alpha_{0}italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the minimum of those angles in (0,œÄ2)0ùúã2(0,\frac{\pi}{2})( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) for which the bent plate is in equilibrium, and it holds that

m‚Å¢g‚Å¢14‚ãÖ18=m‚Å¢g‚Å¢34‚ãÖ(38‚Å¢cos‚Å°(Œ±0)‚àí14).‚ãÖùëöùëî1418‚ãÖùëöùëî3438subscriptùõº014mg\frac{1}{4}\cdot\frac{1}{8}=mg\frac{3}{4}\cdot\left(\frac{3}{8}\cos(\alpha_{% 0})-\frac{1}{4}\right).italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG = italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ‚ãÖ ( divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ) .

Therefore, we get that

‚Ñô‚Å°({the bent plate does not fall over})=‚Ñô‚Å°(Œ±0‚©ΩŒ±<œÄ2)‚Ñôthe bent plate does not fall over‚Ñôsubscriptùõº0ùõºùúã2\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\{\text{the bent plate does not fall % over}\})=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\alpha_{0}\leqslant\alpha<\frac{\pi}{2% }\right)blackboard_P ( { the bent plate does not fall over } ) = blackboard_P ( italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚©Ω italic_Œ± < divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG )
=œÄ2‚àíŒ±0œÄ2=œÄ2‚àíarccos‚Å°(79)œÄ2=1‚àí2‚Å¢arccos‚Å°(79)œÄ‚âà0.5673.absentùúã2subscriptùõº0ùúã2ùúã279ùúã21279ùúã0.5673\displaystyle\qquad\qquad=\frac{\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha_{0}}{\frac{\pi}{2}}=\frac% {\frac{\pi}{2}-\arccos\left(\frac{7}{9}\right)}{\frac{\pi}{2}}=1-\frac{2% \arccos\left(\frac{7}{9}\right)}{\pi}\approx 0.5673.= divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG = 1 - divide start_ARG 2 roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG ‚âà 0.5673 .

(ii). Using the notations introduced in the solution of part (i), we need to calculate the conditional probability ‚Ñô‚Å°(A|A‚à™B)‚Ñôconditionalùê¥ùê¥ùêµ\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\,|\,A\cup B)blackboard_P ( italic_A | italic_A ‚à™ italic_B ). Since the events Aùê¥Aitalic_A and BùêµBitalic_B are disjoint, we get that

‚Ñô‚Å°(A|A‚à™B)=‚Ñô‚Å°(A‚à©(A‚à™B))‚Ñô‚Å°(A‚à™B)=‚Ñô‚Å°(A)‚Ñô‚Å°(A‚à™B),‚Ñôconditionalùê¥ùê¥ùêµ‚Ñôùê¥ùê¥ùêµ‚Ñôùê¥ùêµ‚Ñôùê¥‚Ñôùê¥ùêµ\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\,|\,A\cup B)=\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\cap% (A\cup B))}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\cup B)}=\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}% }(A)}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\cup B)},blackboard_P ( italic_A | italic_A ‚à™ italic_B ) = divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_A ‚à© ( italic_A ‚à™ italic_B ) ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_A ‚à™ italic_B ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_A ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_A ‚à™ italic_B ) end_ARG ,

where, by the solution of part (i),

‚Ñô‚Å°(A‚à™B)=1‚àí2‚Å¢arccos‚Å°(79)œÄ.‚Ñôùê¥ùêµ1279ùúã\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\cup B)=1-\frac{2\arccos\left(\frac{7}{9}\right)}{% \pi}.blackboard_P ( italic_A ‚à™ italic_B ) = 1 - divide start_ARG 2 roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG .

Furthermore, we have that

‚Ñô‚Å°(A)=‚Ñô‚Å°(38‚Å¢cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚©Ω14)=‚Ñô‚Å°(cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚©Ω23).‚Ñôùê¥‚Ñô38ùõº14‚Ñôùõº23\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\frac{3}{8}\cos(% \alpha)\leqslant\frac{1}{4}\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\cos(\alpha)% \leqslant\frac{2}{3}\right).blackboard_P ( italic_A ) = blackboard_P ( divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) ‚©Ω divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ) = blackboard_P ( roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) ‚©Ω divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) .

Here the inequality cos‚Å°(Œ±)‚©Ω23ùõº23\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{2}{3}roman_cos ( italic_Œ± ) ‚©Ω divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG, Œ±‚àà(0,œÄ2)ùõº0ùúã2\alpha\in(0,\frac{\pi}{2})italic_Œ± ‚àà ( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) holds if and only if Œ±‚àà[Œ±1,œÄ2)ùõºsubscriptùõº1ùúã2\alpha\in[\alpha_{1},\frac{\pi}{2})italic_Œ± ‚àà [ italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ), where Œ±1‚àà(0,œÄ2)subscriptùõº10ùúã2\alpha_{1}\in(0,\frac{\pi}{2})italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚àà ( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) is the unique value for which cos‚Å°(Œ±1)=23subscriptùõº123\cos(\alpha_{1})=\frac{2}{3}roman_cos ( italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG, i.e., Œ±1=arccos‚Å°(23)‚âà0.8411subscriptùõº1230.8411\alpha_{1}=\arccos\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)\approx 0.8411italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) ‚âà 0.8411. Consequently, we obtain that

‚Ñô‚Å°(A)=‚Ñô‚Å°(Œ±1‚©ΩŒ±<œÄ2)=œÄ2‚àíŒ±1œÄ2=œÄ2‚àíarccos‚Å°(23)œÄ2=1‚àí2‚Å¢arccos‚Å°(23)œÄ‚âà0.4645.‚Ñôùê¥‚Ñôsubscriptùõº1ùõºùúã2ùúã2subscriptùõº1ùúã2ùúã223ùúã21223ùúã0.4645\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\alpha_{1}% \leqslant\alpha<\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=\frac{\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha_{1}}{\frac{\pi% }{2}}=\frac{\frac{\pi}{2}-\arccos\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)}{\frac{\pi}{2}}=1-% \frac{2\arccos\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)}{\pi}\approx 0.4645.blackboard_P ( italic_A ) = blackboard_P ( italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚©Ω italic_Œ± < divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - italic_Œ± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG = 1 - divide start_ARG 2 roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG ‚âà 0.4645 .

Then we have

‚Ñô‚Å°(A|A‚à™B)=œÄ2‚àíarccos‚Å°(23)œÄ2‚àíarccos‚Å°(79)‚âà0.8189.‚Ñôconditionalùê¥ùê¥ùêµùúã223ùúã2790.8189\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\,|\,A\cup B)=\frac{\frac{\pi}{2}-% \arccos\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)}{\frac{\pi}{2}-\arccos\left(\frac{7}{9}\right)% }\approx 0.8189.blackboard_P ( italic_A | italic_A ‚à™ italic_B ) = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_œÄ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) end_ARG ‚âà 0.8189 .

‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

The following exercise is a randomized version of Problem 2 in Section 7.5 in Sz√≠ki [8].

3.2 Exercise.

Let us consider a homogeneous prismatic beam of length 1 m and mass mùëömitalic_m kg, and its two endpoints and the centre point are denoted by Aùê¥Aitalic_A, BùêµBitalic_B and SùëÜSitalic_S, respectively. The beam is fixed by means of a pin support at its point Aùê¥Aitalic_A, and of a roller support at a point chosen uniformly on the section S‚Å¢BùëÜùêµSBitalic_S italic_B (see Figure 7).

  • (i)

    Let us determine the expected values of the reaction forces at the two supporting points!

  • (ii)

    Are the expected values of the reaction forces calculated in part (i) equal to the reaction forces which correspond to the case when the beam is fixed by means of a pin support at its point Aùê¥Aitalic_A, and of a roller support at the bisection point of the section S‚Å¢BùëÜùêµSBitalic_S italic_B? Why is there no contradiction compared to the result obtained in part (i)?

Solution. (i). Let Cùê∂Citalic_C and Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ denote the point corresponding to the roller support and the length of the section S‚Å¢CùëÜùê∂SCitalic_S italic_C, respectively. Due to the assumptions, Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ is a random variable having uniform distribution on the interval [0,12]012[0,\frac{1}{2}][ 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ]. The reaction forces at the points Aùê¥Aitalic_A and Cùê∂Citalic_C are denoted by ùë≠A=[FA,x,FA,y]‚ä§subscriptùë≠ùê¥superscriptsubscriptùêπùê¥ùë•subscriptùêπùê¥ùë¶top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}=[F_{A,x},F_{A,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùë≠C=[FC,x,FC,y]‚ä§subscriptùë≠ùê∂superscriptsubscriptùêπùê∂ùë•subscriptùêπùê∂ùë¶top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{C}=[F_{C,x},F_{C,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Furthermore, let ùë≠S:=[0,‚àím‚Å¢g]‚ä§assignsubscriptùë≠ùëÜsuperscript0ùëöùëîtop{\boldsymbol{F}}_{S}:=[0,-mg]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := [ 0 , - italic_m italic_g ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note also that the direction of rotation is positive (i.e., counterclockwise) on Figure 7.

The beam is in equilibrium if and only if the resultant force is zero and the resultant moment of the force system that acts on the beam is equal to zero for a given point of the plane. Consequently, the beam is in equilibrium if and only if the resultant force is

(3.1) ùë≠A+ùë≠C+ùë≠S=ùüé,subscriptùë≠ùê¥subscriptùë≠ùê∂subscriptùë≠ùëÜ0\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}+{\boldsymbol{F}}_{C}+{\boldsymbol{F}}_{S}={% \boldsymbol{0}},bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_0 ,

and the resultant moment of forces with respect to the point Aùê¥Aitalic_A is

(3.2) ‚àím‚Å¢g‚ãÖ12+FC,y‚Å¢(12+Œæ)=0.‚ãÖùëöùëî12subscriptùêπùê∂ùë¶12ùúâ0\displaystyle-mg\cdot\frac{1}{2}+F_{C,y}\left(\frac{1}{2}+\xi\right)=0.- italic_m italic_g ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_Œæ ) = 0 .

Using that the point Cùê∂Citalic_C corresponds to a roller support, we have that FC,x=0subscriptùêπùê∂ùë•0F_{C,x}=0italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, and hence, writing the vectors in the equation (3.1) in coordinate form, we get that

(3.3) [FA,xFA,y]+[0FC,y]+[0‚àím‚Å¢g]=[00].matrixsubscriptùêπùê¥ùë•subscriptùêπùê¥ùë¶matrix0subscriptùêπùê∂ùë¶matrix0ùëöùëîmatrix00\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}F_{A,x}\\ F_{A,y}\\ \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}0\\ F_{C,y}\\ \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}0\\ -mg\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\\ \end{bmatrix}.[ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] + [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] + [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - italic_m italic_g end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

This shows that FA,x=0subscriptùêπùê¥ùë•0F_{A,x}=0italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 and FA,y+FC,y=m‚Å¢gsubscriptùêπùê¥ùë¶subscriptùêπùê∂ùë¶ùëöùëîF_{A,y}+F_{C,y}=mgitalic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m italic_g. Further, by (3.2), we obtain that

FC,y=m‚Å¢g2‚Å¢(12+Œæ)=m‚Å¢g‚ãÖ12‚Å¢Œæ+1,subscriptùêπùê∂ùë¶ùëöùëî212ùúâ‚ãÖùëöùëî12ùúâ1F_{C,y}=\frac{mg}{2\left(\frac{1}{2}+\xi\right)}=mg\cdot\frac{1}{2\xi+1},italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_m italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_Œæ ) end_ARG = italic_m italic_g ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ + 1 end_ARG ,

and hence

FA,y=m‚Å¢g‚àíFC,y=m‚Å¢g‚àím‚Å¢g2‚Å¢Œæ+1=m‚Å¢g‚ãÖ2‚Å¢Œæ2‚Å¢Œæ+1.subscriptùêπùê¥ùë¶ùëöùëîsubscriptùêπùê∂ùë¶ùëöùëîùëöùëî2ùúâ1‚ãÖùëöùëî2ùúâ2ùúâ1F_{A,y}=mg-F_{C,y}=mg-\frac{mg}{2\xi+1}=mg\cdot\frac{2\xi}{2\xi+1}.italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m italic_g - italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m italic_g - divide start_ARG italic_m italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ + 1 end_ARG = italic_m italic_g ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ + 1 end_ARG .

Consequently, we have that

(3.4) ùë≠A=[0m‚Å¢g‚ãÖ2‚Å¢Œæ2‚Å¢Œæ+1]andùë≠C=[0m‚Å¢g‚ãÖ12‚Å¢Œæ+1].formulae-sequencesubscriptùë≠ùê¥matrix0‚ãÖùëöùëî2ùúâ2ùúâ1andsubscriptùë≠ùê∂matrix0‚ãÖùëöùëî12ùúâ1\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg\cdot\frac{2\xi}{2\xi+1}\\ \end{bmatrix}\qquad\text{and}\qquad{\boldsymbol{F}}_{C}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg\cdot\frac{1}{2\xi+1}\\ \end{bmatrix}.bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ + 1 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] and bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ + 1 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

Therefore, the expected values of the reaction forces at the points Aùê¥Aitalic_A and Cùê∂Citalic_C take the following forms:

ùîº‚Å°(ùë≠A)=[0m‚Å¢g‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(2‚Å¢Œæ2‚Å¢Œæ+1)]=[0m‚Å¢g‚Å¢(1‚àíln‚Å°(2))],ùîºsubscriptùë≠ùê¥matrix0ùëöùëîùîº2ùúâ2ùúâ1matrix0ùëöùëî12\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}({\boldsymbol{F}}_{A})=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{2\xi}{2\xi+1}\right)\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg(1-\ln(2))\\ \end{bmatrix},blackboard_E ( bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ + 1 end_ARG ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g ( 1 - roman_ln ( 2 ) ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ,

and

ùîº‚Å°(ùë≠C)=[0m‚Å¢g‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(12‚Å¢Œæ+1)]=[0m‚Å¢g‚Å¢ln‚Å°(2)],ùîºsubscriptùë≠ùê∂matrix0ùëöùëîùîº12ùúâ1matrix0ùëöùëî2\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}({\boldsymbol{F}}_{C})=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{1}{2\xi+1}\right)\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg\ln(2)\\ \end{bmatrix},blackboard_E ( bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ + 1 end_ARG ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g roman_ln ( 2 ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ,

since

ùîº‚Å°(12‚Å¢Œæ+1)=‚à´01/212‚Å¢x+1‚ãÖ2‚Å¢dx=ln‚Å°(2)‚àíln‚Å°(1)=ln‚Å°(2),ùîº12ùúâ1superscriptsubscript012‚ãÖ12ùë•12differential-dùë•212\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{1}{2\xi+1}\right)=\int_{0}^{% 1/2}\frac{1}{2x+1}\cdot 2\,\mathrm{d}x=\ln(2)-\ln(1)=\ln(2),blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ + 1 end_ARG ) = ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_x + 1 end_ARG ‚ãÖ 2 roman_d italic_x = roman_ln ( 2 ) - roman_ln ( 1 ) = roman_ln ( 2 ) ,
ùîº‚Å°(2‚Å¢Œæ2‚Å¢Œæ+1)=1‚àíùîº‚Å°(12‚Å¢Œæ+1)=1‚àíln‚Å°(2),ùîº2ùúâ2ùúâ11ùîº12ùúâ112\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{2\xi}{2\xi+1}\right)=1-% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{1}{2\xi+1}\right)=1-\ln(2),blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ + 1 end_ARG ) = 1 - blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ + 1 end_ARG ) = 1 - roman_ln ( 2 ) ,

where we used Newton-Leibniz formula and that a primitive function of the function [0,12]‚àãx‚Ü¶2/(2‚Å¢x+1)contains012ùë•maps-to22ùë•1[0,\frac{1}{2}]\ni x\mapsto 2/(2x+1)[ 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ] ‚àã italic_x ‚Ü¶ 2 / ( 2 italic_x + 1 ) is [0,12]‚àãx‚Ü¶ln‚Å°(2‚Å¢x+1)contains012ùë•maps-to2ùë•1[0,\frac{1}{2}]\ni x\mapsto\ln(2x+1)[ 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ] ‚àã italic_x ‚Ü¶ roman_ln ( 2 italic_x + 1 ).

(ii). Similarly to the solution of part (i) (formally replacing Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ by 1414\frac{1}{4}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG in the formula (3.4)), we get that

ùë≠A=[0m‚Å¢g3]andùë≠C=[02‚Å¢m‚Å¢g3].formulae-sequencesubscriptùë≠ùê¥matrix0ùëöùëî3andsubscriptùë≠ùê∂matrix02ùëöùëî3{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ \frac{mg}{3}\\ \end{bmatrix}\qquad\text{and}\qquad{\boldsymbol{F}}_{C}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ \frac{2mg}{3}\\ \end{bmatrix}.bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_m italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] and bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG 2 italic_m italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

Since 13‚â†1‚àíln‚Å°(2)1312\frac{1}{3}\neq 1-\ln(2)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ‚â† 1 - roman_ln ( 2 ) and 23‚â†ln‚Å°(2)232\frac{2}{3}\neq\ln(2)divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ‚â† roman_ln ( 2 ), the reaction forces above are not equal to the expected reaction forces calculated in the solution of part (ii). This is not a contradiction, since ùîº‚Å°(12‚Å¢Œæ+1)‚â†1ùîº‚Å°(2‚Å¢Œæ+1)=12‚ãÖ14+1=23ùîº12ùúâ11ùîº2ùúâ11‚ãÖ214123\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\frac{1}{2\xi+1})\neq\frac{1}{\operatorname{\mathbb{% E}}(2\xi+1)}=\frac{1}{2\cdot\frac{1}{4}+1}=\frac{2}{3}blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Œæ + 1 end_ARG ) ‚â† divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_E ( 2 italic_Œæ + 1 ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG + 1 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

3.3 Exercise.

The plate with the dimensions given in Figure 8 is fixed by means of a pin support at point Aùê¥Aitalic_A and a rope at point BùêµBitalic_B, and is subjected to concentrated forces ùë≠1subscriptùë≠1{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùë≠2subscriptùë≠2{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. Assume that the mass of the plate can be neglected, and the magnitude of the forces ùë≠1subscriptùë≠1{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùë≠2subscriptùë≠2{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is 300300300\,300N and 100100100\,100N, respectively. Further, we suppose that the distribution of bùëèbitalic_b is uniform distribution on the interval (0‚Å¢m,3‚Å¢m)0m3m(0\,\mathrm{m},\sqrt{3}\,\mathrm{m})( 0 roman_m , square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG roman_m ).

  • (i)

    What is the distribution of the rope force at point BùêµBitalic_B?

  • (ii)

    What is the probability that the magnitude of the rope force at point BùêµBitalic_B is in the interval [400‚Å¢3‚Å¢N,400‚Å¢3+100‚Å¢N]4003N4003100N\left[400\sqrt{3}\,\mathrm{N},400\sqrt{3}+100\,\mathrm{N}\right][ 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG roman_N , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + 100 roman_N ]?

  • (iii)

    What is the expected value of the magnitude of the rope force at point BùêµBitalic_B?

  • (iv)

    What is the expected value of the force at point Aùê¥Aitalic_A?

Solution. Let us denote by ùë≠Asubscriptùë≠ùê¥{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùë≠Bsubscriptùë≠ùêµ{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the forces at the points Aùê¥Aitalic_A and BùêµBitalic_B, respectively. In part (i) we need to determine the distribution of ‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñnormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à•; in part (ii) the probability ‚Ñô‚Å°(‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñ‚àà(400‚Å¢3,400‚Å¢3+100))‚Ñônormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ40034003100\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|\in(400\sqrt{3},400\sqrt{3}+% 100))blackboard_P ( ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚àà ( 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + 100 ) ); in part (iii) the expected value of ‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñnormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à•; and in part (iv) the expected value of ùë≠Asubscriptùë≠ùê¥{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Recall that the coordinates of a vector ùíóùíó{\boldsymbol{v}}bold_italic_v in the (x,y)ùë•ùë¶(x,y)( italic_x , italic_y )-plane are denoted by vxsubscriptùë£ùë•v_{x}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vysubscriptùë£ùë¶v_{y}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively, i.e., ùíó=(vx,vy)ùíósubscriptùë£ùë•subscriptùë£ùë¶{\boldsymbol{v}}=(v_{x},v_{y})bold_italic_v = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Accordingly, we have ùë≠1=[F1,x,F1,y]‚ä§subscriptùë≠1superscriptsubscriptùêπ1ùë•subscriptùêπ1ùë¶top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}=[F_{1,x},F_{1,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ùë≠2=[F2,x,F2,y]‚ä§subscriptùë≠2superscriptsubscriptùêπ2ùë•subscriptùêπ2ùë¶top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}=[F_{2,x},F_{2,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ùë≠A=[FA,x,FA,y]‚ä§subscriptùë≠ùê¥superscriptsubscriptùêπùê¥ùë•subscriptùêπùê¥ùë¶top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}=[F_{A,x},F_{A,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ùë≠B=[FB,x,FB,y]‚ä§subscriptùë≠ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùêπùêµùë•subscriptùêπùêµùë¶top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}=[F_{B,x},F_{B,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚ä§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We have ‚Äñùë≠1‚Äñ=300normsubscriptùë≠1300\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}\|=300‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• = 300, ‚Äñùë≠2‚Äñ=100normsubscriptùë≠2100\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}\|=100‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• = 100, and
