We take the direction of rotation as positive (i.e., counterclockwise) on Figure 8. Hence the moments M1ùê¥ùê¥subscriptùëÄ1\underset{A}{M_{1}}underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, M2ùê¥ùê¥subscriptùëÄ2\underset{A}{M_{2}}underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG and MBùê¥ùê¥subscriptùëÄùêµ\underset{A}{M_{B}}underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG of the forces ùë≠1subscriptùë≠1{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ùë≠2subscriptùë≠2{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ùë≠Bsubscriptùë≠ùêµ{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to the point Aùê¥Aitalic_A are

M1ùê¥:=‚Äñùë≠1‚Äñ‚ãÖcos‚Å°(30360‚ãÖ2‚Å¢œÄ)‚ãÖ(2+b)=300‚Å¢32‚Å¢(2+b)=150‚Å¢3‚Å¢(2+b),assignùê¥subscriptùëÄ1‚ãÖnormsubscriptùë≠1‚ãÖ303602ùúã2ùëè300322ùëè15032ùëè\displaystyle\underset{A}{M_{1}}:=\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}\|\cdot\cos\left(\frac% {30}{360}\cdot 2\pi\right)\cdot(2+b)=300\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}(2+b)=150\sqrt{3}(2+% b),underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG := ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚ãÖ roman_cos ( divide start_ARG 30 end_ARG start_ARG 360 end_ARG ‚ãÖ 2 italic_œÄ ) ‚ãÖ ( 2 + italic_b ) = 300 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 2 + italic_b ) = 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( 2 + italic_b ) ,
M2ùê¥:=‚Äñùë≠2‚Äñ‚ãÖcos‚Å°(45360)‚ãÖ1.5‚àí‚Äñùë≠2‚Äñ‚ãÖsin‚Å°(45360)‚ãÖ2=150‚Å¢22‚àí100‚Å¢2=‚àí25‚Å¢2,assignùê¥subscriptùëÄ2‚ãÖnormsubscriptùë≠2453601.5‚ãÖnormsubscriptùë≠2453602150221002252\displaystyle\underset{A}{M_{2}}:=\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}\|\cdot\cos\left(\frac% {45}{360}\right)\cdot 1.5-\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}\|\cdot\sin\left(\frac{45}{360% }\right)\cdot 2=150\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}-100\sqrt{2}=-25\sqrt{2},underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG := ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚ãÖ roman_cos ( divide start_ARG 45 end_ARG start_ARG 360 end_ARG ) ‚ãÖ 1.5 - ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚ãÖ roman_sin ( divide start_ARG 45 end_ARG start_ARG 360 end_ARG ) ‚ãÖ 2 = 150 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 100 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG = - 25 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ,
MBùê¥:=‚àí‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñ‚ãÖcos‚Å°(60360‚ãÖ2‚Å¢œÄ)‚ãÖ1.5=‚àí‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñ‚ãÖ12‚ãÖ1.5=‚àí34‚Å¢‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñ.assignùê¥subscriptùëÄùêµ‚ãÖnormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ‚ãÖ603602ùúã1.5‚ãÖnormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ121.534normsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\displaystyle\underset{A}{M_{B}}:=-\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|\cdot\cos\left(% \frac{60}{360}\cdot 2\pi\right)\cdot 1.5=-\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|\cdot\frac{1% }{2}\cdot 1.5=-\frac{3}{4}\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|.underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG := - ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚ãÖ roman_cos ( divide start_ARG 60 end_ARG start_ARG 360 end_ARG ‚ãÖ 2 italic_œÄ ) ‚ãÖ 1.5 = - ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚ãÖ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚ãÖ 1.5 = - divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• .

Since the plate is balanced, the equilibrium of forces in the directions xùë•xitalic_x and yùë¶yitalic_y and that of the moment of forces with respect to the point Aùê¥Aitalic_A are as follows:

FA,x+FB,x+F1,x+F2,x=0,subscriptùêπùê¥ùë•subscriptùêπùêµùë•subscriptùêπ1ùë•subscriptùêπ2ùë•0\displaystyle F_{A,x}+F_{B,x}+F_{1,x}+F_{2,x}=0,italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 ,
FA,y+FB,y+F1,y+F2,y=0,subscriptùêπùê¥ùë¶subscriptùêπùêµùë¶subscriptùêπ1ùë¶subscriptùêπ2ùë¶0\displaystyle F_{A,y}+F_{B,y}+F_{1,y}+F_{2,y}=0,italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 ,
MBùê¥+M1ùê¥+M2ùê¥=0.ùê¥subscriptùëÄùêµùê¥subscriptùëÄ1ùê¥subscriptùëÄ20\displaystyle\underset{A}{M_{B}}+\underset{A}{M_{1}}+\underset{A}{M_{2}}=0.underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = 0 .

This system of equations takes the form

FA,x+12‚Å¢‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñsubscriptùêπùê¥ùë•12normsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\displaystyle F_{A,x}+\frac{1}{2}\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• =150+50‚Å¢2,absent150502\displaystyle=150+50\sqrt{2},= 150 + 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ,
FA,y+32‚Å¢‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñsubscriptùêπùê¥ùë¶32normsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\displaystyle F_{A,y}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• =150‚Å¢3‚àí50‚Å¢2,absent1503502\displaystyle=150\sqrt{3}-50\sqrt{2},= 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ,
‚àí34‚Å¢‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñ34normsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\displaystyle-\frac{3}{4}\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|- divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• =‚àí150‚Å¢3‚Å¢(2+b)+25‚Å¢2.absent15032ùëè252\displaystyle=-150\sqrt{3}(2+b)+25\sqrt{2}.= - 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( 2 + italic_b ) + 25 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG .

This is a system of linear equations in the variables FA,xsubscriptùêπùê¥ùë•F_{A,x}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, FA,ysubscriptùêπùê¥ùë¶F_{A,y}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñnormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à•. It follows from the last equation that

‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñ=400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2+200‚Å¢3‚Å¢b.normsubscriptùë≠ùêµ4003100322003ùëè\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|=400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+200\sqrt{3}b.‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• = 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_b .

Substituting the value of ‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñnormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• to the second equation, we get that

FA,y=150‚Å¢3‚àí50‚Å¢2‚àí600+50‚Å¢63‚àí300‚Å¢b.subscriptùêπùê¥ùë¶15035026005063300ùëèF_{A,y}=150\sqrt{3}-50\sqrt{2}-600+50\frac{\sqrt{6}}{3}-300b.italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 600 + 50 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 6 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 300 italic_b .

By substituting the value of ‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñnormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• to the first equation, we have

FA,x=150+2003‚Å¢2‚àí200‚Å¢3‚àí100‚Å¢3‚Å¢b.subscriptùêπùê¥ùë•1502003220031003ùëèF_{A,x}=150+\frac{200}{3}\sqrt{2}-200\sqrt{3}-100\sqrt{3}b.italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 150 + divide start_ARG 200 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 100 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_b .

(i). Since bùëèbitalic_b has a uniform distribution on the interval (0,3)03(0,\sqrt{3})( 0 , square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG ), its cumulative distribution function takes the form

‚Ñô‚Å°(b<x)={0if¬†x‚©Ω0,x3if¬†x‚àà(0,3),1if¬†x‚©æ3.‚Ñôùëèùë•cases0if¬†x‚©Ω0ùë•3if¬†x‚àà(0,3)1if¬†x‚©æ3\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(b<x)=\begin{cases}0&\text{if $x\leqslant 0$},\\ \frac{x}{\sqrt{3}}&\text{if $x\in(0,\sqrt{3})$},\\ 1&\text{if $x\geqslant\sqrt{3}$}.\end{cases}blackboard_P ( italic_b < italic_x ) = { start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ‚©Ω 0 , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ‚àà ( 0 , square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ‚©æ square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG . end_CELL end_ROW

Hence the cumulative distribution function of ‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñnormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• can be written as

‚Ñô‚Å°(‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñ<x)=‚Ñô‚Å°(400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2+200‚Å¢3‚Å¢b<x)‚Ñônormsubscriptùë≠ùêµùë•‚Ñô4003100322003ùëèùë•\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|<x)=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+200\sqrt{3}b<% x\right)blackboard_P ( ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• < italic_x ) = blackboard_P ( 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_b < italic_x )
=‚Ñô‚Å°(b<x‚àí400‚Å¢3+1003‚Å¢2200‚Å¢3)absent‚Ñôùëèùë•4003100322003\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(b<\frac{x-400\sqrt{3}+\frac{100}{% 3}\sqrt{2}}{200\sqrt{3}}\right)= blackboard_P ( italic_b < divide start_ARG italic_x - 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG )
={0if¬†x‚©Ω400‚Å¢3+1003‚Å¢2,x‚àí400‚Å¢3+1003‚Å¢2200‚Å¢3if¬†x‚àà(400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2,400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2+600),1if¬†x‚©æ400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2+600.absentcases0if¬†x‚©Ω400‚Å¢3+1003‚Å¢2,ùë•4003100322003if¬†x‚àà(400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2,400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2+600),1if¬†x‚©æ400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2+600.\displaystyle=\begin{cases}0&\text{if $x\leqslant 400\sqrt{3}+\frac{100}{3}% \sqrt{2}$,}\\ \frac{x-400\sqrt{3}+\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}}{200\sqrt{3}}&\text{if $x\in\left(40% 0\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2},400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+600\right)$,% }\\ 1&\text{if $x\geqslant 400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+600$.}\end{cases}= { start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ‚©Ω 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_x - 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ‚àà ( 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 600 ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ‚©æ 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 600 . end_CELL end_ROW

Consequently, ‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñnormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• has a uniform distribution on the interval

(400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2,400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2+600).400310032400310032600\left(400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2},400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+600% \right).( 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 600 ) .

(ii). Using the results in the solution of part (i), we get that

‚Ñô‚Å°(‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñ‚àà[400‚Å¢3,400‚Å¢3+100])‚Ñônormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ40034003100\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|\in\left[4% 00\sqrt{3},400\sqrt{3}+100\right]\right)blackboard_P ( ‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• ‚àà [ 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + 100 ] )
=400‚Å¢3+100‚àí400‚Å¢3+1003‚Å¢2600‚àí400‚Å¢3‚àí400‚Å¢3+1003‚Å¢2600=16.absent4003100400310032600400340031003260016\displaystyle=\frac{400\sqrt{3}+100-400\sqrt{3}+\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}}{600}-% \frac{400\sqrt{3}-400\sqrt{3}+\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}}{600}=\frac{1}{6}.= divide start_ARG 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + 100 - 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 600 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 600 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG .

We note that this probability can be calculated using geometric probabilities as well. Namely, the length of the interval [400‚Å¢3,400‚Å¢3+100]40034003100\left[400\sqrt{3},400\sqrt{3}+100\right][ 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + 100 ] and (400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2,400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2+600)400310032400310032600\left(400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2},400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+600\right)( 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 600 ) is 100100100100 and 600600600600, respectively, and hence the probability in question is 100600=1610060016\frac{100}{600}=\frac{1}{6}divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 600 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG.

(iii). The expected value of ‚Äñùë≠B‚Äñnormsubscriptùë≠ùêµ\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|‚à• bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚à• is

400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2+400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2+6002=400‚Å¢3‚àí1003‚Å¢2+300‚âà945.7.4003100324003100326002400310032300945.7\dfrac{400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+600% }{2}=400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+300\approx 945.7.divide start_ARG 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 600 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 300 ‚âà 945.7 .

(iv). The expected value of ùë≠Asubscriptùë≠ùê¥{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is

ùîº‚Å°(ùë≠A)ùîºsubscriptùë≠ùê¥\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}({\boldsymbol{F}}_{A})blackboard_E ( bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =[ùîº‚Å°(FA,x)ùîº‚Å°(FA,y)]=[ùîº‚Å°(150+2003‚Å¢2‚àí200‚Å¢3‚àí100‚Å¢3‚Å¢b)ùîº‚Å°(150‚Å¢3‚àí50‚Å¢2‚àí600+50‚Å¢63‚àí300‚Å¢b)]absentmatrixùîºsubscriptùêπùê¥ùë•ùîºsubscriptùêπùê¥ùë¶matrixùîº1502003220031003ùëèùîº15035026005063300ùëè\displaystyle=\begin{bmatrix}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(F_{A,x})\\ \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(F_{A,y})\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}150+\frac{200}{3}% \sqrt{2}-200\sqrt{3}-100\sqrt{3}b\big{)}\\ \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}150\sqrt{3}-50\sqrt{2}-600+50\frac{\sqrt{6}}{3% }-300b\big{)}\\ \end{bmatrix}= [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E ( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E ( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E ( 150 + divide start_ARG 200 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 100 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_b ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E ( 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 600 + 50 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 6 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 300 italic_b ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ]
=[150+2003‚Å¢2‚àí200‚Å¢3‚àí100‚Å¢3‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(b)150‚Å¢3‚àí50‚Å¢2‚àí600+50‚Å¢63‚àí300‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(b)].absentmatrix1502003220031003ùîºùëè15035026005063300ùîºùëè\displaystyle=\begin{bmatrix}150+\frac{200}{3}\sqrt{2}-200\sqrt{3}-100\sqrt{3}% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(b)\\ 150\sqrt{3}-50\sqrt{2}-600+50\frac{\sqrt{6}}{3}-300\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(b% )\\ \end{bmatrix}.= [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 150 + divide start_ARG 200 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 100 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG blackboard_E ( italic_b ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 600 + 50 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 6 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 300 blackboard_E ( italic_b ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

Using that ùîº‚Å°(b)=32ùîºùëè32\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(b)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}blackboard_E ( italic_b ) = divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG, we have that

ùîº‚Å°(ùë≠A)=[2003‚Å¢2‚àí200‚Å¢3‚àí600‚àí50‚Å¢2+50‚Å¢63]‚âà[‚àí252.1‚àí629.9].ùîºsubscriptùë≠ùê¥matrix2003220036005025063matrix252.1629.9\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}({\boldsymbol{F}}_{A})=\begin{bmatrix}% \frac{200}{3}\sqrt{2}-200\sqrt{3}\\ -600-50\sqrt{2}+50\frac{\sqrt{6}}{3}\\ \end{bmatrix}\approx\begin{bmatrix}-252.1\\ -629.9\\ \end{bmatrix}.blackboard_E ( bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG 200 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - 600 - 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 50 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 6 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ‚âà [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL - 252.1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - 629.9 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

‚ñ°‚ñ°\Box‚ñ°

4 Concluding remarks

Our method for incorporating a stochastic point of view into physics exercises of mathematics education may be used in several different ways by high school students and teachers and by first-year university students. The core of the method is the randomization of some inputs, the system model used does not differ from what we would use in the deterministic approach. We demonstrate our method of randomization of some inputs by considering exercises from the theory of projectile motion and statics. Students may be asked to create similar exercises, for other fields of physics as well. Our stochastic perspective can help the students recognize the fact that many phenomena in our daily lives have a random nature, and therefore it can be useful to get in touch with stochastic thinking and tools in order to be able to understand these phenomena much better. Computer simulations using Monte Carlo methods might also be assigned to our elaborate examples in order to confirm the solutions empirically.

Appendices

Appendix A Basic knowledge of probability

In this appendix, we recall some of the notations, conventions, concepts and results of probability theory that are used in solving the exercises.

In all of the paper, (Œ©,ùíú,‚Ñô)Œ©ùíú‚Ñô(\Omega,{\mathcal{A}},\operatorname{\mathbb{P}})( roman_Œ© , caligraphic_A , blackboard_P ) denotes a probability space, where Œ©Œ©\Omegaroman_Œ© is called sample space. A mapping Œæ:Œ©‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúâ‚ÜíŒ©‚Ñù\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_Œæ : roman_Œ© ‚Üí blackboard_R is called a random variable if {œâ‚ààŒ©:Œæ‚Å¢(œâ)<x}‚ààùíúconditional-setùúîŒ©ùúâùúîùë•ùíú\{\omega\in\Omega:\xi(\omega)<x\}\in{\mathcal{A}}{ italic_œâ ‚àà roman_Œ© : italic_Œæ ( italic_œâ ) < italic_x } ‚àà caligraphic_A for all x‚àà‚Ñùùë•‚Ñùx\in\mathbb{R}italic_x ‚àà blackboard_R. By a 2222-dimensional random vector, we mean a mapping (Œæ,Œ∑):Œ©‚Üí‚Ñù2:ùúâùúÇ‚ÜíŒ©superscript‚Ñù2(\xi,\eta):\Omega\to\mathbb{R}^{2}( italic_Œæ , italic_Œ∑ ) : roman_Œ© ‚Üí blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ and Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ are (1-dimensional) random variables. Given a random variable Œæ:Œ©‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúâ‚ÜíŒ©‚Ñù\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_Œæ : roman_Œ© ‚Üí blackboard_R and a real number x‚àà‚Ñùùë•‚Ñùx\in\mathbb{R}italic_x ‚àà blackboard_R, we use the notational conventions {Œæ<x}:={œâ‚ààŒ©:Œæ‚Å¢(œâ)<x}assignùúâùë•conditional-setùúîŒ©ùúâùúîùë•\{\xi<x\}:=\{\omega\in\Omega:\xi(\omega)<x\}{ italic_Œæ < italic_x } := { italic_œâ ‚àà roman_Œ© : italic_Œæ ( italic_œâ ) < italic_x }, and accordingly ‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ<x):=‚Ñô‚Å°({Œæ<x})assign‚Ñôùúâùë•‚Ñôùúâùë•\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi<x):=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\{\xi<x\})blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ < italic_x ) := blackboard_P ( { italic_Œæ < italic_x } ).

Given events A,B‚ààùíúùê¥ùêµùíúA,B\in{\mathcal{A}}italic_A , italic_B ‚àà caligraphic_A such that ‚Ñô‚Å°(B)>0‚Ñôùêµ0\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(B)>0blackboard_P ( italic_B ) > 0, the conditional probability of Aùê¥Aitalic_A given BùêµBitalic_B is defined by ‚Ñô‚Å°(A‚à©B)‚Ñô‚Å°(B)‚Ñôùê¥ùêµ‚Ñôùêµ\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\cap B)}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(B)}divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_A ‚à© italic_B ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_B ) end_ARG, and is denoted by ‚Ñô‚Å°(A|B)‚Ñôconditionalùê¥ùêµ\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\,|\,B)blackboard_P ( italic_A | italic_B ). Given events A,B‚ààùíúùê¥ùêµùíúA,B\in{\mathcal{A}}italic_A , italic_B ‚àà caligraphic_A such that ‚Ñô‚Å°(A)‚àà(0,1)‚Ñôùê¥01\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)\in(0,1)blackboard_P ( italic_A ) ‚àà ( 0 , 1 ) and ‚Ñô‚Å°(B)>0‚Ñôùêµ0\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(B)>0blackboard_P ( italic_B ) > 0, Bayes‚Äôs theorem states that

(A.1) ‚Ñô‚Å°(A|B)=‚Ñô‚Å°(B|A)‚Å¢‚Ñô‚Å°(A)‚Ñô‚Å°(B|A)‚Å¢‚Ñô‚Å°(A)+‚Ñô‚Å°(B|Œ©‚àñA)‚Å¢‚Ñô‚Å°(Œ©‚àñA).‚Ñôconditionalùê¥ùêµ‚Ñôconditionalùêµùê¥‚Ñôùê¥‚Ñôconditionalùêµùê¥‚Ñôùê¥‚ÑôconditionalùêµŒ©ùê¥‚ÑôŒ©ùê¥\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\,|\,B)=\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}% }(B\,|\,A)\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(B\,|\,A)% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(B\,|\,\Omega\setminus A% )\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\Omega\setminus A)}.blackboard_P ( italic_A | italic_B ) = divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_B | italic_A ) blackboard_P ( italic_A ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_B | italic_A ) blackboard_P ( italic_A ) + blackboard_P ( italic_B | roman_Œ© ‚àñ italic_A ) blackboard_P ( roman_Œ© ‚àñ italic_A ) end_ARG .

In some cases, we calculate the probability of an event using the method of geometric probabilities. In this case, the underlying probability space is chosen as a (Borel) subset SùëÜSitalic_S of ‚Ñù2superscript‚Ñù2\mathbb{R}^{2}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT furnished with the sigma-algebra ‚Ñ¨‚Å¢(S)‚Ñ¨ùëÜ{\mathcal{B}}(S)caligraphic_B ( italic_S ) generated by all of the open subsets of SùëÜSitalic_S (i.e., with the Borel sigma-algebra of SùëÜSitalic_S), and, for all A‚àà‚Ñ¨‚Å¢(S)ùê¥‚Ñ¨ùëÜA\in{\mathcal{B}}(S)italic_A ‚àà caligraphic_B ( italic_S ), the probability ‚Ñô‚Å°(A)‚Ñôùê¥\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)blackboard_P ( italic_A ) of Aùê¥Aitalic_A is defined as the fraction of the area (2222-dimensional Lebesgue measure) of Aùê¥Aitalic_A and that of SùëÜSitalic_S, where we suppose that the area of SùëÜSitalic_S is positive.

The cumulative distribution function of a random variable Œæ:Œ©‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúâ‚ÜíŒ©‚Ñù\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_Œæ : roman_Œ© ‚Üí blackboard_R is defined by FŒæ:‚Ñù‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùêπùúâ‚Üí‚Ñù‚ÑùF_{\xi}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R ‚Üí blackboard_R, FŒæ‚Å¢(x):=‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ<x)assignsubscriptùêπùúâùë•‚Ñôùúâùë•F_{\xi}(x):=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi<x)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ < italic_x ), x‚àà‚Ñùùë•‚Ñùx\in\mathbb{R}italic_x ‚àà blackboard_R. A random variable is called discrete if its range Œæ‚Å¢(Œ©)ùúâŒ©\xi(\Omega)italic_Œæ ( roman_Œ© ) is countable. By the (probability) distribution of a discrete random variable Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ having range Œæ(Œ©)=:{xi:i‚àà‚Ñï}\xi(\Omega)=:\{x_{i}:i\in\mathbb{N}\}italic_Œæ ( roman_Œ© ) = : { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_i ‚àà blackboard_N }, we mean the sequence (‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=xi))i‚àà‚Ñïsubscript‚Ñôùúâsubscriptùë•ùëñùëñ‚Ñï(\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=x_{i}))_{i\in\mathbb{N}}( blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ‚àà blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A random variable Œæ:Œ©‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúâ‚ÜíŒ©‚Ñù\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_Œæ : roman_Œ© ‚Üí blackboard_R is called absolutely continuous if there exists a (Borel measurable) non-negative function fŒæ:‚Ñù‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùëìùúâ‚Üí‚Ñù‚Ñùf_{\xi}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R ‚Üí blackboard_R such that FŒæ‚Å¢(x)=‚à´‚àí‚àûxfŒæ‚Å¢(t)‚Å¢dtsubscriptùêπùúâùë•superscriptsubscriptùë•subscriptùëìùúâùë°differential-dùë°F_{\xi}(x)=\int_{-\infty}^{x}f_{\xi}(t)\,\mathrm{d}titalic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) roman_d italic_t, x‚àà‚Ñùùë•‚Ñùx\in\mathbb{R}italic_x ‚àà blackboard_R. The expected value (expectation) and of a discrete random variable Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ having range Œæ(Œ©)=:{xi:i‚àà‚Ñï}\xi(\Omega)=:\{x_{i}:i\in\mathbb{N}\}italic_Œæ ( roman_Œ© ) = : { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_i ‚àà blackboard_N } is defined by ùîº‚Å°(Œæ):=‚àëi=1‚àûxi‚Å¢‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=xi)assignùîºùúâsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ñôùúâsubscriptùë•ùëñ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi):=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}x_{i}\operatorname{\mathbb{% P}}(\xi=x_{i})blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) := ‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), provided that ‚àëi=1‚àû|xi|‚Å¢‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ=xi)<‚àûsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùë•ùëñ‚Ñôùúâsubscriptùë•ùëñ\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}|x_{i}|\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=x_{i})<\infty‚àë start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) < ‚àû. The expected value (expectation) of an absolutely continuous random variable Œæ:Œ©‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúâ‚ÜíŒ©‚Ñù\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_Œæ : roman_Œ© ‚Üí blackboard_R with a density function fŒæsubscriptùëìùúâf_{\xi}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is defined by ùîº‚Å°(Œæ):=‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àûx‚Å¢fŒæ‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢dxassignùîºùúâsuperscriptsubscriptùë•subscriptùëìùúâùë•differential-dùë•\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi):=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}xf_{\xi}(x)\,\mathrm{d}xblackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) := ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_d italic_x, provided that ‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àû|x|‚Å¢fŒæ‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢dx<‚àûsuperscriptsubscriptùë•subscriptùëìùúâùë•differential-dùë•\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|x|f_{\xi}(x)\,\mathrm{d}x<\infty‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x | italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_d italic_x < ‚àû. The variance and standard deviation of a random variable Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ is defined by ùîª2‚Å°(Œæ):=ùîº‚Å°((Œæ‚àíùîº‚Å°(Œæ))2)assignsuperscriptùîª2ùúâùîºsuperscriptùúâùîºùúâ2\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}^{2}(\xi):=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}((\xi-% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi))^{2})blackboard_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Œæ ) := blackboard_E ( ( italic_Œæ - blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and ùîª‚Å°(Œæ):=ùîº‚Å°((Œæ‚àíùîº‚Å°(Œæ))2)assignùîªùúâùîºsuperscriptùúâùîºùúâ2\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}(\xi):=\sqrt{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}((\xi-% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi))^{2})}blackboard_D ( italic_Œæ ) := square-root start_ARG blackboard_E ( ( italic_Œæ - blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG, respectively, provided that ùîº‚Å°(Œæ2)<‚àûùîºsuperscriptùúâ2\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi^{2})<\inftyblackboard_E ( italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < ‚àû. It is know that ùîª2‚Å°(Œæ)=ùîº‚Å°(Œæ2)‚àí(ùîº‚Å°(Œæ))2superscriptùîª2ùúâùîºsuperscriptùúâ2superscriptùîºùúâ2\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}^{2}(\xi)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi^{2})-(% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi))^{2}blackboard_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Œæ ) = blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - ( blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The relative standard deviation (also known as coefficient of variation) of a positive random variable Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ having finite second moment (i.e., ùîº‚Å°(Œæ2)<‚àûùîºsuperscriptùúâ2\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi^{2})<\inftyblackboard_E ( italic_Œæ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < ‚àû) is given by RSD‚Å°(Œæ):=ùîª‚Å°(Œæ)/ùîº‚Å°(Œæ)assignRSDùúâùîªùúâùîºùúâ\operatorname{RSD}(\xi):=\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}(\xi)/\operatorname{\mathbb{% E}}(\xi)roman_RSD ( italic_Œæ ) := blackboard_D ( italic_Œæ ) / blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ). Roughly speaking, the higher relative standard deviation of a nonnegative random variable Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ, the greater the level of dispersion of the values of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ around its mean ùîº‚Å°(Œæ)ùîºùúâ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ). If (Œæ,Œ∑)ùúâùúÇ(\xi,\eta)( italic_Œæ , italic_Œ∑ ) is a 2222-dimensional random vector such that ùîº‚Å°(Œæ)ùîºùúâ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) and ùîº‚Å°(Œ∑)ùîºùúÇ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\eta)blackboard_E ( italic_Œ∑ ) are defined, then the expectation vector of (Œæ,Œ∑)ùúâùúÇ(\xi,\eta)( italic_Œæ , italic_Œ∑ ) is given by ùîº‚Å°(Œæ,Œ∑):=(ùîº‚Å°(Œæ),ùîº‚Å°(Œ∑))assignùîºùúâùúÇùîºùúâùîºùúÇ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi,\eta):=(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi),% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\eta))blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ , italic_Œ∑ ) := ( blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) , blackboard_E ( italic_Œ∑ ) ). If Œæ:Œ©‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúâ‚ÜíŒ©‚Ñù\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_Œæ : roman_Œ© ‚Üí blackboard_R is a random variable such that ùîº‚Å°(Œæ)ùîºùúâ\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) is defined and a,b‚àà‚Ñùùëéùëè‚Ñùa,b\in\mathbb{R}italic_a , italic_b ‚àà blackboard_R, then ùîº‚Å°(a‚Å¢Œæ+b)ùîºùëéùúâùëè\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(a\xi+b)blackboard_E ( italic_a italic_Œæ + italic_b ) is defined as well and

(A.2) ùîº‚Å°(a‚Å¢Œæ+b)=a‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(Œæ)+b.ùîºùëéùúâùëèùëéùîºùúâùëè\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(a\xi+b)=a\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)% +b.blackboard_E ( italic_a italic_Œæ + italic_b ) = italic_a blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) + italic_b .

If Œæ,Œ∑:Œ©‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúâùúÇ‚ÜíŒ©‚Ñù\xi,\eta:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_Œæ , italic_Œ∑ : roman_Œ© ‚Üí blackboard_R are random variables, then the function FŒæ,Œ∑:‚Ñù2‚Üí‚Ñù:subscriptùêπùúâùúÇ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñù2‚ÑùF_{\xi,\eta}:\mathbb{R}^{2}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ , italic_Œ∑ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R, FŒæ,Œ∑‚Å¢(x,y):=‚Ñô‚Å°(Œæ<x,Œ∑<y)assignsubscriptùêπùúâùúÇùë•ùë¶‚Ñôùúâùë•ùúÇùë¶F_{\xi,\eta}(x,y):=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi<x,\eta<y)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ , italic_Œ∑ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) := blackboard_P ( italic_Œæ < italic_x , italic_Œ∑ < italic_y ), x,y‚àà‚Ñùùë•ùë¶‚Ñùx,y\in\mathbb{R}italic_x , italic_y ‚àà blackboard_R, is called the joint distribution function of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ and Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑. The random variables Œæ,Œ∑:Œ©‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúâùúÇ‚ÜíŒ©‚Ñù\xi,\eta:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_Œæ , italic_Œ∑ : roman_Œ© ‚Üí blackboard_R are called independent if FŒæ,Œ∑‚Å¢(x,y)=FŒæ‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢FŒ∑‚Å¢(y)subscriptùêπùúâùúÇùë•ùë¶subscriptùêπùúâùë•subscriptùêπùúÇùë¶F_{\xi,\eta}(x,y)=F_{\xi}(x)F_{\eta}(y)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ , italic_Œ∑ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œæ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y ), x,y‚àà‚Ñùùë•ùë¶‚Ñùx,y\in\mathbb{R}italic_x , italic_y ‚àà blackboard_R, i.e., the joint distribution function of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ and Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ is the product of the distribution functions of Œæùúâ\xiitalic_Œæ and Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑. (A.3) ùîº‚Å°(Œæ‚Å¢Œ∑)=ùîº‚Å°(Œæ)‚Å¢ùîº‚Å°(Œ∑).ùîºùúâùúÇùîºùúâùîºùúÇ\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi\eta)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\eta).blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ italic_Œ∑ ) = blackboard_E ( italic_Œæ ) blackboard_E ( italic_Œ∑ ) .

Finally, we formulate the law of total expectation that is used in the solution of Exercise 2.1. Let (Œ©,ùíú,‚Ñô)Œ©ùíú‚Ñô(\Omega,\mathcal{A},\operatorname{\mathbb{P}})( roman_Œ© , caligraphic_A , blackboard_P ) be a probability space, Œæ:Œ©‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúâ‚ÜíŒ©‚Ñù\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_Œæ : roman_Œ© ‚Üí blackboard_R and Œ∑:Œ©‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúÇ‚ÜíŒ©‚Ñù\eta:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_Œ∑ : roman_Œ© ‚Üí blackboard_R are independent random variables such that Œ∑ùúÇ\etaitalic_Œ∑ is absolutely continuous with a density function fŒ∑subscriptùëìùúÇf_{\eta}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then for any (Borel measurable) function G:‚Ñù2‚Üí‚Ñù:ùê∫‚Üísuperscript‚Ñù2‚ÑùG:\mathbb{R}^{2}\to\mathbb{R}italic_G : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚Üí blackboard_R, we have that

(A.4) ‚Ñô‚Å°(G‚Å¢(Œæ,Œ∑)<z)=‚à´‚àí‚àû‚àû‚Ñô‚Å°(G‚Å¢(Œæ,r)<z)‚Å¢fŒ∑‚Å¢(r)‚Å¢dr,z‚àà‚Ñù.formulae-sequence‚Ñôùê∫ùúâùúÇùëßsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñôùê∫ùúâùëüùëßsubscriptùëìùúÇùëüdifferential-dùëüùëß‚Ñù\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(G(\xi,\eta)<z)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(G(\xi,r)<z)f_{\eta}(r)\,\mathrm{d}r,\qquad z\in% \mathbb{R}.blackboard_P ( italic_G ( italic_Œæ , italic_Œ∑ ) < italic_z ) = ‚à´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ‚àû end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ‚àû end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_G ( italic_Œæ , italic_r ) < italic_z ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œ∑ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) roman_d italic_r , italic_z ‚àà blackboard_R .

Appendix B Basic knowledge of mechanics

In this appendix, we provide some concepts of mechanics used in solving the exercises.

Motion in a homogeneous gravitational field (projectile motion) is discussed in the simplest planar model, assuming that the drag force (air resistance) is negligible. In this case, the only force acting on a point-like object is the constant gravitational force (m‚ãÖg‚ãÖùëöùëîm\cdot gitalic_m ‚ãÖ italic_g), and the equation of the motion is a parabola. This type of motion is the superposition of a uniform motion in the horizontal direction and a uniformly accelerated motion (‚Äùfree fall‚Äù) in the vertical direction.

In general, the initial velocity is arbitrary; its two components are the initial velocities in the horizontal and vertical directions. In our examples, only one of the initial velocity components is different from zero. Since the relevant formulas are well known and can be found in high school physics textbooks, we will not list them here. When solving the exercises, we will simply recall and apply them. Here we only mention the book by de Lange and Pierrus [2, Section 7] where one can find several interesting exercises with detailed solutions for two and three dimensional projectile motions.

The following is a list of some basic static concepts used in Section 3. A prismatic beam is a beam with a uniform cross-section throughout. Reaction forces are the forces exerted by the supports on the beam to achieve equilibrium of a force system. Two basic types of supports are used in this paper. The first one is the pinned support, which can resist forces in any direction, but not rotation. It allows the beam to rotate, but not to translate in any direction. In this case the reaction force can be any force in the plane, i.e. its components can be different from zero in any direction. The second one is the roller support which is free to rotate and translate along the surface on which the roller rests. In this case, the reaction force is perpendicular to and away from the surface (in particular, its component parallel to the surface is zero).

The rotating effect of a force with respect to a (fixed) point is described by its moment of force, which is a scalar quantity in planar problems. The convention is that the sign of the moment of force is positive if it rotates counterclockwise in the plane. The magnitude of the moment of a force with respect to a point (point of rotation) is the product of the magnitude of the force and its lever arm, where the lever arm is the distance between the point of rotation and the line of action of the force.

To determine unknown reaction forces in a equilibrium situation of a rigid body in the plane, we can write equilibrium equations for the forces and the moments of forces. One type of the equilibrium equations says that the sum of force vectors is zero. In planar problems it means two scalar equations in two perpendicular directions (e.g. horizontal and vertical). In planar problems, the other type of the equilibrium equations says that the sum of scalar moments of forces with respect to an arbitrary point of the plane is zero. All in all, a rigid body in the plane is in equilibrium if the sum of the force vectors acting on it is zero and the sum of the corresponding scalar moments of forces with respect to an arbitrary point of the plane is zero.
